DEFINITION'S
(a) Compensation: The pavment in cash or k-ind for private property acquired by the
RMIDP. based on replacement value as defined by the Compensation Determination
Coimmittee (CDC).
(b) Compensation  Determination  Committee (CDC): The district-level committee
established under Section 13 (2) of the Land Accluisition .4ct, 2034 (197?) to determine
replacement value and compensation rates for property acquired under the Act.
(c) Corridor of Impact (COI): For newr roads. the COI (or initial ROW) is set at 15 m
(i.e. 7.5 m on either side of the centerline), except where construction requirements
and topography necessitate the acquisition of a wider area. The COI should be clear of
habitation and agricultural activities and is therefore the area wvhere direct ne-ative
project impacts wvill occur. For upgradiing roads. the COI is defined as the road
formation plus a safety zone where necessary. Asset acquisition will only take place
where required for upgrading purposes (e.g. road widening and realignment) or safety
reasons. Other assets outside the COI will be left undisturbed.
(d) Cut-off Date for Eligibilitv to Entitlements: The cut-off date for eligibilitv to
compensation and assistance under the Entitlement Frameework. This date will be the
date of the joint census of affected households and affected assets.
(e) Entitled Person (EP): Any person %vho is entitled to (i) compensation under the
Entitlement Framework because of the loss of privately-owned assets and/or (ii) other
rehabilitation assistance.
(f) Encroachers and Squatters: Encroachers are land-ownincg persons from  adjacent
settlements wNho have established commercial enterprises or practice cultivation on
public land wvithin the COI of existing roads. Squatters are landless persons occupying
public land within the COI of existing roads.
,,             (g) Local Consultative Forums (LCFs): Thc VDC-level committees established to assist
the affected population. CDCs and project authorities with the identification of
potential replacement land where required. monitoring of imrplementation issues and
communitv reactions. and grievance resolution.
(h) Povertv Line Income (PLI): The cost of maintaining, basic. minimum needs. PLIs
have been defined by different oruanisations and governmCnt departments. using
factors such as per capita calorie requirements and expenditure on housing and other
non-food items.
T). 7C* i-nC1 I i''r'drn2 Comnoncnw



Nepal: Road Mvainitenance and Developiment Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                          Resettlemeeit Action Plan
(i) Project Affected Person (PAP): Any person directly affected by the project through
the acquisition of assets belonging to him/her or his,her household or community. This
includes any person whose rights. standard of living. subsistence and income-
generating capacity are adversely affected through the acquisitioni of assets. whether
full/partial. or permanent/temporary.
j) Project Affected Family (PAF): The group of people residing in one h1ouse
(includingz temporary absent members such as students) and operatin_ as a single
economic unit. who are adverselv affected by the project. A PAF may conlsists of an
extended family (e.g. husband and xife. plus married soIIs. daughlters in law  and
gJrandchildren). Major children over the age of 18 vears will be entitled  to
rehabilitation measures as outlined in the Entitlement Matrix but not to compensation
for properties held by other members of the houselhold. A Seriously Project Affected
Family (SPAF) is defined as:
*  a household who has to be resettled because of the acquisition of its house. business
enterprise, or rcnted accommodation: or
*  a household from whom land acquisition exceeds 25 % of its total landholdings. in the
casc of landholdings larger than 0.25 ha. or 10% of its total landholdin_s. in the case of
landholdingts of 0.25 ha or smaller. or w-here land losses lead to the remainin(
landholding not being- economically viable (as identified through the participatory
application of context-specific criteria).
(k) Project Affected Group (PAG): Communities or groups wvho lose comMunity
resources to the project.
(I) Rehabilitation: The measures taken to mitigate identified social impacts. includine
compensation. resettlement and rehabilitation and transition allowvances where
required.
(m)Replacement cost: The open/fair market value of a project-affected property. For
agricultural land. this includes reference to land of equal size. type and productive
potential in the vicinity of the affected land and land preparation costs whele required.
For houses and other buildings. this includes reference to the market price of materials
and labour. and the cost of transporting materials to the building site. Replacenment cost
further includes the cost of anv re-istration and transfer taxes for land and buildinls.
(n) Titleholder: The person in whose name the project-affected land and/or buildin2 is
reg,istered and \vho is authorised bv law to receive the compensationi granted for the
acquisition of the land.
(o) Tenant: A person occupying/utilising land of a titleholder according to thle stipulatiolns
of the La1m7lA.4cr. 2021 (1964).
(p) Vulnerable  Groups: Social categories whose  livelihoods mnay  be particularly
vultler-able to disturbances created by the project. These -rotips may include tribal
groups and landless persons wvho rely on access to local agricUltutral w-ork and other
sUpport systems built tip around the agriculttiral resource base.



MNpal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                                 Resettleient Action Plan
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Introduction
* I            His Mvlajesty's Goveninient of Nepal (Ministry of 'Works and Transport. Department of
Roads) is preparing  a Road  Maintenance and  Development Project (RM4DP). wvith
assistance fiom the WVorld Bank. The RMIDP is concernied with the strategic road network
1and comprises (a) periodic maintenaince of the core netxmork- and (b) construction and
improvement of road access to non-road-served hill/mouLntain districts. usin( lowv-cost.
labour-based  methods. The  cuIrreit study  is concerned  with  the  second  of these
components.
Five of the roads identified in the Priority  Investmiienit Plan (PIP) wvere selected for
consideration in the RMDP.. uwitlh a furtlher thlee non-PIP roads added. The eight roads
xverc scrccncd dow-n (as part of the initial RMDP activities) to five sections of new roads
and four sections of existing earth roads for upgrading to gravel fair wveather standards.
One of the upgrading  roads (Sitalpati-Tharmare. DoR  Classification  No. FIS) was
subsequentlv eliminated follow-ing economic re-evaluation. leavinm  the folloving roads
and road leng2ths:

Social Development Potential
Nepal is one of the poorest countries in the xuorld. with up to 45 %.o of its populationi
defined as "poor (HMG/N. 1996b: UNDP 1998: 126). The new roads in the RMDP arc
5                situLted in the Far-Westem Development Region (FWDR) and Mid-Western Development
Region (MWDR). tVo of the most unlder-de-eloped reoions in the country. Four of the six
districts crossed by the new roads are amongst the 10 worst-performing districts of Nepal.
Achhamii District-is rated as the worst performing district. followed bv Kaliklot. Jumla.
Bajura and Jajarkot Districts. Darchula District is also fairly poorly rated (26"'). Twxo of
the five districts crossed by the upgrading roads (Dailekh and Salvaan) are also poorly rated
(1 o,h and 1 6'' respectively), while Kapilbastu. Ar-ghakhachi and Surkhet Districts are rated
highler.
New Road Development and Upgrading Component                          Executive Summary Page i



Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Finial Report: Volume 8                                           Resettlemient Actioi Plan       U
HMIGN's Eight Plan (1992-1997). as well as the AgricLlItural-Perspective Plan. emplhasise
the importance of' rural road linklages in the developmlenm process. The rural population. in
particular. is restricted from  participatingz in economic growth. because of inadequate
access to healtlh. education. transport. communication and mar;ket facilities. Apart froml the
periodic repair and maintenance of highvvavs. the Eilht Plan. therefore. proposed the
construction of 1.200 kimi of rLiral roads. 125 kmin of main tracks and 830 knm of mule trails
(HG,/N  I 997e). As a componient of the infrastructure development programnme. the
RMDP. particularly the new- road section. is anticipated to aid the Government's poverty
alleviation efforts as detailed in the Ninth Plan.
This emphasis on the role of roads in economic growth and poverty alleviation higholihts          3
the fact that roads create opportunities for development: fior example. by stinmulatingo new
or enhlaniced income-gencrating opportunities. These indirect impacts are often muchI niore
significant tlhan the direct impacts caused during road conistruction (e.g. land acquisitioil).
since they maav induce endurinu socioeconomic changes. The positive reaction of roadside
Communities and district officials to road constr-Lctioln. uLnderscores the importance
attached to these indirect impacts. It was frequently stated. for example. thiat thie roads
would improve access to market areas. lead 10 a reduction in the cost of imported
hoouselhold goods (consumner items). create opportuLities lor the export of crops and
stimulate local developm ent. Their support of the project does niot imply a lackl of concern
over property losses (the effect of land losses in particular). but a belief that the
development potential associated w-ith the roads outweighs direct adverse impacts.
Given the kev features of the socioeconomic environmiienit (as detailed in the RAP and
Env'ironmental Impact Assessment). the following key indirect impacts may result from
road construction:
*  Potential for human development through an improvement in access to essential
services. The nexv roads. for instance. are anticipated to improve general mobility and
access for an estimated population of 124,3 14 in the road VDCS. and nearly 370.000
in thie roads' wider zones of influence (HMG,/N. 1998c). For people in close proximitv
to the roads. this benefit is considerable. More distantly-located people. too. will
benefit from the newv roads. since their journey time to services and opportuLnities in
the Terai and elsewhere  wihile remaining high. will nevertheless be significantly
reduced.
*  New or adjusted economilc opportunities witllin the agricultural and off-farm sectors.
through easier access to agricultural inputs (e.g. fertiliser and seeds). the creation of
opportunities for the export of agricultural and livestock products. and opportunities
for the establishmenit of local businesses. The n.w- roacds may reduce the use of porters
and other providers of non-vehlicular transport. reduce the cLiltivation prOductioI lev els
of  households wvhose land is acquired. btut also lead to an increase in land prices alongJ
the road and at market areas.
*  An improvement in food supply and a reductioni in the cost of consumer itemiis.
Ain improvement in the overall hcaltlh status of' people and a reductioll in child
mortality  rates. through  i mproved  access to  health  facilities. counselling  and
inloibnmationi.
*  Possible increases in literacy rates through improved access to education.

I
Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                            Resettlement Action Plan
*  AIn improvement in the position of vulnerable social categories and groups. through
the creation and stimulation of income-generatingT opportLnities and a reduction in
social and economic disparities.
Substantive increases in levels of humani development depend not only on improved
access to existinai facilities. but also on accompanying developments in the non-road
sector (e.g. increases in the number of healtlh facilities and schlools). W'hile it is difficult to
I ]             separate road-itnduced impacts from other regionial/national development efforts. evidence
from other hill/mounitain roads. nevertheless. suggests that roads do have a development
effect. since their primary benefits (increased access and mobility) are available to a wvide
pool of people.
The evidence also showvs that a profit-maximising, response to newv  and enhanced
commiiercial opportunities in the acricultural sector is not necessarily automatic. It is more
likely wlhere tlhere alrcady is an established comnmercial agricultural sector. together with
associated credit services, input supplies and marketing  arrangenments. Additionally.
subsistence farmiers may (understandably) be averse to diverting resources away from  a
knownvi and secure form  of farming  practice to  a commercial one whichi carries
considerable risks. Thus. while the newv roads will create the potential for economllic
diversification. and wvhile nearly all of the household respondents believed that the roads
would provide these opporttnities. it may take time for them to be fully realised.
3               Road Construction Employment
Access to construction employment opportunities is often regarded as an important (albeit
short-term) beneficial impact associated Nilth a development. The maximisation of local
participationi in road constluctioni and maintenance should. therefore. be encouraged. From
discussions  with a sample of contractors. the biQgest constrainit to achievina this aim
appears to  be the unavailability/irregular supply  of local workers  resulting  from
agricultural oblig,ations and seasonal labouL migration. Individual and group discussions in
roadside settlements. on the other hand. show that people are concerned about being paid
fair wages for work on road construction.
Three initernationial organisation were also  asked to  share thieir experiences with
comrmunity-based road construction projects in Nepal (GTZ. Care Nepal and Helvetas).
All of themii highly recommended the cemiploymn1enat of local persons. stating that it creates
local income-gieneratingi opportunities. helps to overcome food deficiencies. contributes to
A              poverty-alleviation and promotes skills development. The unavailability of local -workers
duriing key agricultural periods (i.e. planting and harvesting) and for other social
obligations (e.g. festivals) may lead to irTegular wNork attendance and interruptiolns of'
construction schedLiles. However. if properly plann2ed  and nmonitored. thiere is no
disadvantage in employing local workers.
a                Approach To Resettlement Planning
The Ri\lDP is being prepared tinder HM1G/Ni policies and World Banik guidelines. Banlk
policy entphasises the need to avoid or milniMise involuntary resettlement on development
projects. UWhere  the  acquisition  of privatc  propcrtv  is unavoidable. involuntar%
resettlement should be an integral part of project design and preparation (Operational
Directive 4.30/Operational Policy 4.12).

HMG/fN policy. too. acknowledges the importance of avoiding adverse socio-economic
impacts in road design and construLction: in fixing the road alignment. an attem1pt slhould
be made to avoid areas of small land parcels. homes. shops and other structures. and to
nminimise the number of people Nwho will have to be resettled   judgemnent must be used
when agricultural land is utilised for road constructioln .. the acquisitioni of strips of prim11e
agTricultural land from a small famn  could makie farming unprofitable-' (HMG/N. 19997d).
The preparation of the R.\IDP lhas been guided by! these Government and Banlk objectiVes.
and social considerationis have. as far as possible. been incorporated into alignment
selection and road desiTn. However, geolog,ical and topographical factors. as xvell as land
use and seTtlement patterns, maae the acquisition of'private property for road construction      I
inevitable. A key objective directing the development of thlis Resettlement Actiotn Plan
(RAP) lhas therefore been to ensure that tlhe pre-project living standards of aff'ected persons
are restored (and where possible improxed) at no cost to themnselves. This will be achieved
through the mneasLures specilied in the project's Entitlemenit Framework.
Thie successf'ul implementation of these mzeasuLres requilres an enabling. supportivc
environment. ''his will be achieved throughI- the following objectives:
*  Ongoing commun11itV consultationi Will occur to ensure that people's views. concerns
and suggestions. particularly those of vulnerable groups, are satisfactorily incorporated
into implementation procedures.
-  An institutional fiamework xvill be developed as an integral part of the project to
ensure that appropriate social impact management mechanisms are set up and
mainitained during implemlienitationi. These mechanisms and arranenments will ensure
iltat compensation. resettlemenlt and  rehabilitation  are carried  out timeli  and
effectivelv.
-  Constructioni work will commence oIn road sections only after acquisition procedures
as detailed in the Entitlemient FrameNwork, have been successfullx initiated.
Efforts to Minimise Social Impacts
The primacy of geological and topographical considerations in road constructioni in Nepal-
restricts the extent to which social and environmental considerations caln have a bearnM  on
new  road alignment selection. Within this constraint. the slhortest possible length was
selected to min1imise land take. while thie alignnments wvere refined to avoid or reduce
impacts oni archaeological. reli-ious and cultur-al sites: large settlements. high-value
production land: hich conservaliona forests areas; and rainfed cultivation.
In ani effort to further recluce the substantial impact that land acquisition wvould have on1
hiouselhoid production levels. adjustments were t    adce to the Riglt of Wax (normally
between 30 mi - 50 In for feeder roads and highways) specified in DoR design standards.
ThLere is little douibl that the land take areas for the two sets of roads (as defined below)
has grcatly redticcd populationi displacement and othel social impacts.
For i7cnw  ioads the CO) (or initial ROW') is set at 15 rn. except wvhere constniction
requir-emiients anid topoiraphy  necessitate the acquisition of a wider area. Property
acquisition will be limited to the COI and other assets outside the COI wvill be left
unldisturbed.

safetv reasons. Other assets wvill be left undisturbed.

Entitlement Framework
Through the Entitlement Framework (detailed in Chapter 5 of the RAP). the project is
committed to eiisure that the livelilhoods of project-affected persons are at least restored to
pre-pr-oject levels. with the opportunity to improve on livi'ng standards wvhere possible. The
Frame-work addresses the followino impacts associated  with  road  construction  and
upgrading:
*  loss of land and other privately-ovned assets:
*  adv-erse impacts o01 subsistence. livelihood or income-earning capacity, and
New Road Development and Upgrading Componient                     Executive Summary Pa-e v



Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                          Resenlement Action Plan
*  collective adverse impacts on -roups (e  loss o0 communal resources and assets).
To mitigate unforeseen effects on roadside communities and promote general upliftment.
rehabilitation and support measures will be extended to include vulnerable social
categories whlo may be adverselv affected by road construction,.
Entitlements are organised around categories of loss (e.g. cultivation land. residential
structure. commercial establishiment) to ensure that persons who suffer more than one type
of loss. receive compensation or rehabilitation suppoit for each cateitorv of loss.
Entitlements have been developed according to domestic legislation and supplemenited.
vwhere necessary. with additional measures to comply! with World Bank specitications.
Entitlements for land losses are in the form  of cash compensation. Throughout Nepal.
cultivation land is at a premium  and replacement land is. accordingly, not readily
available. Areas not under cultivation are generally not suitable for crop production
(because of factors such as slope and poor soil quality), while agricultural resettlemient on
2overnment-owned forest land is pro,hibited. Every effort will. nevertheless. be mzade to
provide additional land-based options to households whose production levels are severely
affected by land acquisition. This wvill primarily be achiievcd througLh Local Consultative
Forums (LCFs). established at VDC-level to assist with thc identification of suitable
privatelv-owsied cultivation land in tlle vicinity for purchasing by affected households.
The current DoR practice of obtainingy land through donations will also be allowed.
provided that procedures as laid out in the Entitlement Framework are adhered to. Thcse
include that:
*  affected owners are informed of their right to compensation fJor the acquired iand:
-  affected owners and communities participate equallY  wNith project authorities in
aliinment selection: and
*  each donation is u;ll'N recorded and verified by the donor. DoR and relevant district
and local officials.
For buildings. as well. compensation will be in cash. For fully acquired houses. twvo
approaches will be followed. Displaced houLseholds with alternative accommodationi will
receive a cash lump sUlml payment.- Displaced households whlo do not have alternatiVe
accommodation will receive their compensation in two instalments: an initial payment and
a final payment after the  construction  of replacement housing  has successfully
commenced. Formal resettlement planningu will be undertaken where more than 10
hoLIseholds tfrom the same settlement/lesidenitial area have to be relocated. 
Project-affected persons will be given written notice of the intent to acquire theirl
properties in accordance with the provisions of the Land Acquisilion Ael. They wvill
fturthermore be given xvritten notice to vacate their properties not less thian 35 days prior to
the intended acquisition date.
H1M&G/N will not take possession of any private property prior to the full payment of
compenisation entitlemiients and. where applicable. initiation of relocation arrangements
and economic rehabilitation measures. The project will maake everv eff'ort to enstUre that
displaced lhouseholds have access to replacement housing prior to their evacuation from

the COI. through appropriate advance compensation and shifting allowvaance payments at
the time of serving the notice to vacate. or other forms of relocation assistance agreed \vith
the concerned houselholds

Census and Asset V'erification

were accompanied by engineering staff who pegged the new road centrelines or identified
upgrading requiremiienits (e.g. road wvidening) and likelv areas of land acquisitioll.

1.0 INTRODUCTION
]              1.1   PROJECT BACKGROUND
As part of its ongoing Road Maintenance and Rehabilitation Project. His Majesty's
Government of Nepal (HIMG/rN) has recently prepared a ten year Priority Investment Plan
(PIP) for the road sector. The PIP includes both the strategic road network (national
hih\vav and feeder roads) and rural transport components. Based on the PIP findings.
HMG,/N (inistrv of Works and Transport. Department of Roads). is preparing a Road
7~}            Maintenance and Development Project (RMDP) witlh assistance fronm the World Bank.
The RMDP is concerned with the stratecic road network- and comprises (a) periodic
maintenance of the core network and (b) construction and improvement of road access to
non-road-served hill/mountain districts. usinu low-cost. labour-based methods. The current
-~ istudv is concerned wvith the second of these components.
The PIP prioritised 10 new  roads that would provide connections to districts in the
Eastern. Mid-Western and Far-Western Reuions. Five of these were selected for
consideration in the Ri9IDP. with a further three non-PIP roads added. The eight candidate
roads. consistingt of 12 upgrading and construction sections. totalled approximately 637
km. These wvere screened down as part of' the initial RMDP activities to five sections of
newv roads (totallin(t approximately 204 kni) and four sections of existing earth roads for
upgrading to gravel fair weather standards (totalling approximately 278 km)-' One of the
upgrading roads (Sitalpati-Tharmare. DoR Classification No. F15) was subsequentlv
eliminated followvine economic re-evaluation. leaving the followino roads and road
lengths:

1.2    SOCIAL IMIPACTS
Road constrLctioll (and to a lesser degree. road upgrading) w-ill have a range of positive
and necative socio-economic impacts. Positive impacts x\ill be experienced at both inacro
and micro levels. for example. improved access to markLets and other social services for
people resident within a road's region of influence, and the potential for diversification of
local economic activities. Negative social impacts are primarily related to the loss of assets             -
within a road's corridor of' impact. disturbances to subsistence and livelihood. as well as
less-quantifiable effects on vulnerable social categories and gyroups.
Table 2: Losses and Potential Social Effects Associated with the RMDP

1.3    AIMS OF THE RESETTLEMENT ACTION PLAN
The principal aim  of the Resettlement Action Plan (RAP) is to address these social
impacts  and  ensure  the  successful  rehabilitation  of project-affected  h1ouseholds.
Specifically. the RAP details:
*  private  and  community  resources  affected  bv  the  project (e.g. land. houses.
infrastructure. etc.)  and  the  entitlements  required  for effectire  household  re-
establishment:
*  the likely number of individuals and households aflfected by the project and the                         |
number of households that may be displaced:
*  oraganisational and institutional requiremnents for the implementation of comlpensationi.
resettlemilenit and rehabilitationi actixvities:
*  impleimienitation schedutles and monitoringr mechanismns: and
*  compensation. resettlemient arid reliabilitatioin cost cstirmatcs.
Most of thie new roads arc presently under construction (as earth roads) as part of DoR's ongoing road
developmenti programme.

1.4      NIETHODS AND LIMITATIONS
1.4.1     Research Mlethods
The RAP research metlhods and results are delailed in the various annexes to this report. In
summarv. a Social Impact Assessment (SIA) wvas undertaken. follow^Ned by a census of
potentiallv affected persons and verification of their affected assets.
1.4.1.1   Social Impact Assessment
The SIA wvas undertaken as part of a broader Environment Impact Assessment (EIA) for
new roads and Initial Environment Examinations (IEEs) for upgrading roads.2 A scoping
exercise (which included a scopino meeting with key stakleholders) identified the
followino kev social issues for investioation:
*  loss of private property and other assets (e.g. cultivation land and houses) and
Ji                 compensation modalities for these losses:
-  population displacement:
*  construction employment opportunities: and
- potential for general social development.
The SIA wvas undertaken in two phases. coincidina with enuineerin2 survevs. For new
roads. fieldwork- commenced with walkoxver surveys by multi-discipliniarv teams to refine
the recommended alignments Followinc these initial surveys. a traverse survey  w as
]               undertaken for each alionment during whichi the social aspects teams undertook more
detailed data collection of human habitation and activities within the 30 m traverse
corridor.
A slightly differetnt approach was used on the upgrading roads. DoR has not legally
acquired the Right of Way (ROW) on any of these roads and. consequently. does not
possess strip maps or other documentation showing ROW  boundaries. In order to link
social data to road chainages. the social aspects teams. therefore, undertook data collection
only after completion of the initial engtineernn  inventory surveys. The latter onlv involves
an assessment of the road surface and associated structures (e.g. drainage lines). while
3               specilc upgrading/\\orks requirements are produced in a subsequent engineering exercise.
.Accordinalv. the initial SIA fieldwork could not include the identification and survev-inu
of persons cac/ztctll/ affected by upgrading. since this informationi only becomes available
after completion of the engineering feasibility studies.
2 Thc primar\ domestic iegislation governing the preparation of an environment assessment is the
I              Enr,rojnnsmonenr Troeci  .ct. 20.53 (EPA) and the Emni,-un77mez7t Pruteictin Regildiions. 2054. Other
-uidelines include the Nolitonul ElA Gvidelines (1993) and the Draft EL4 Guidlinfles for the Rucacl Sector
(1997).

2.0 APPROACH AND OPERATIONAL FRAMEWORK
2.1      APPROACH
The RMDP is being prepared uLnder HMG,IN' policies and W'orld Bank- cuidelin1es. Bank
policy emphasises the need to avoid or minimise involuntary resettlement on development
projects. Where the acquisitioni of private * property  is unavoidable. involuntar-
resettlement should be an integral part of project design and preparation (Operational
Directive 4.30/Operational Policy 4.12).
HMG/N policy. too. acknow-ledges the importance ol' avoiding adverse socio-econom7ic
impacts in road desiun and construction: "in fixing, the road alignrment. an attempt should
be made to avoid areas of small land parcels. homes. shops and other structures. and to
minimise the number of people wlho will have to be resettled ... judgement must be used
whien atgricultural land is Lutilised for road constructioni ... the acquisition of strips of prime
aaricultural land from a small farm could niakLe farnming unprofitable" (HMG/N. ]997d).
'Tlhe preparation of the RMDP has been guided by these Government and Banlk objectiVes.
and social considerations have. as far as possible. been incorporated into alignment
selection and road design. However. geological and topographical factors. as well as land
use and settlement patterns. make the acquisitioni of private property for road construction
inevitable. A key objective directing the development of tlis Resettlement Action Plan has
therefore been to ensure th'at the pre-project living standards of affected persons are
restored (and where possible improved) at no cost to themselves. This will be achieved
througLLh the measures specified in the project's Entitlement Framewvork.
The successful implement:ition of these measures requires an enabling, supportive
environment. This wsill be achieved through the follovwing objectives:
*  Onzoine community consultation xvill occur to ensure that people's views. conceens
and suggestions. particularly those of vulnerable groups. are satisfactorily incorporated
into implementation procedures.
*  An institutional framework will be developed as an integral part of the project to
ensure that appropriate social impact management mechanismiis are set Up and
maintained duringy implementation. Thcsc mechaniismiis and arrangements Will ensure
that compensation. resettlemaenit and rehabilitation are carried  out timelk  and
effectim eI\.
*  Constructioni wxork will commil1enice on road sectionls onlyN after acquisition procedules
as detailed in the Entitlement Framework have beell successfull- initiated.

EFFORTS TO MINIMISE ADVERSE SOCIAL IMPACTS
2.2.1     Design Considerations
Two concerns domiinate road design in Nepal: geology and topography. Geological
considerations dictate that prioritv is given to the selection of the most stable road
3              landscape. Active landslides and areas with a higah potential for landslides are avoided to
achieve long-term road stability. Topographical considerations give prioritv to areas that
are not flood-prone. that maximise embankment stability, and have a lower slope to
niminimise cut and fill and construction costs. Related to the latter is a central DoR
requirement that the new, roads in the RMDP are designed as low cost roads according to
"fair weather track standards.
The primacy of these physical factors and design prerequisites restricts the extent to which
* I          social and environmental considerations can have a bearing on aliwgnment selection: social
considerations are taken into account. but seldom as the overridino criterion for alignment
selection.
The road alignments wxere planned using two sources of information: DoR's alignment
recommendations (based on initial desiLn studies) and alignment refinement undertaken
during- the wvalkover surveys as part of the initial RMDP activities.
The walkover surveys were undertaken  by multi-disciplinary teams consisting of
engineers. geologists. environmentalists and social scientists. Apart from oeological and
X              topographical considerations. their assessment and refinement of the initial alig,nments
L              wvere based on selection of the shortest possible length to minimise land take and
avoidance of. or reduction in impacts on. the following prioritised list of features:
3             *  archaeological. religiious and cultural sites;
larme settlements:
-2             *  high-value production land:
*  higth conservation forests areas:
J3             *  rainfed cultivation: and
degraded forest areas. arassland. etc.
Alicnment changes to minimise impacts in one area frequentlN lead to new or increased
impacts in other areas. For example. at Sridhuska village (Talium VDC) on Kalikot-Jumla.
tthe displacement of 17 households was avoided, but the realignment had to traverse
cultivated land.
Followinu the wvalkover surveys. a detailed (traverse) survey xas undertaken for each
alionment within the parameters of DoR's desigzn specifications and the selection criteria
listed above. The detailed survey aliunment generallv follo1wed the w-alkover aligynment.
buLt occasionally differed substantially due to the need to fit standard road specifications.
NccN KRoad Dcx clopment ind U pruading CompOncmi                           RAP, Page 7



,Nepal: Road Maintenance and Developmient Proiect
Final Report: Volume 8                                                   Resetnlement Action Plan
or to avoid features not previously recorded. The detailed survey data was used to set the
preliminary design alignment (by means of CivilCad) within the surveyed corridor. The
CivilCad Road Designer set the alignmenit by folloxvinq the shape of the terrain (both
horizontally and vertically). wherever possible and within DoR desigon specifications. in
order to minimise earthworks and the number anid size of retainine structures.-:
2.2.2      Corridor of Impact
Nepal's econorny revolves aroudll  subsistence agriculture, yet cultivation land comprises
less than 20% of the countrv's total land area. In an effort to reduce the substantial inipact
that land acquisition would have ont household production levels. adjustments were made
to the Right of Way (normally between 30 m  - 50 m  for feeder roads and hiuhwavs
specified  in DoR  desi-n  standards. Accordinuflv. for the new-v and  upgrading  road
components. land  acquisition  will respectivel]  be limited  to  the  following  impact
corridors:4
*   For neiw, roads the COI (or initial ROW) is set at 15 m. except where construction
requirements and topography necessitate the acquisition of a wider area. Property
acquisition will be limited to the COI and other assets outside the COI will be left
undisturbed.
For ex.sti'n?g roads the COI is defined as the existint- road fornmation plus a safety zone
where necessary. To further miminise population displacement. land acquisition will
only take place where required  for upgrading purposes (e.g. road N-ideninu and
realignment) or safety reasons. Other assets wvill be lett undistLIrbed.
2.2.3      Land Take
Chapter Three presents information  on the reduction  in impact on private land and
buildings resulting from  the selection of narrower impact corridors. In surnmary. the
followinz have been achieved on the new road sections:

Other featuLes of the preriminarv deshin inclide: (a) a standard road w idth of 4.5 II plus 0.6 m widening
(total .1 ni). increased to 6.1 In to accommodate trapezoidal side drains w%here required: (b) an additional
15 % earthworks (cut) allowance to accommilodate 3 m x, ide passing bays: and (c) horizontal location of the
centrelinie close to the natural slope surface (on slopes of less thaln 50t) to reduce excavation and the Volume1C
of excess fill.
4Land acquisition tor road construction is generally based on land donationis (i.e. affected owners do not
receive compensation for land losses). For most existino roads. DoR has not legally acquired the ROV' as
defined in design specitfications. On these roads (including all the upgrading sections in the RNIDP) DoR has
therefore established a muich narrower ROW. namely thc actual road surface area and associated structures.

]                2.3    EiNTITLEMENT FRAMEWORK
Throu_h the Entitlement Framework (Chapter 5). the project is committed to ensure that
the livelihoods of project-affected persons are at least restored to pre-project levels. w-ith
the opportunity to improve on livin- standards where possible. The Policv addresses the
following adverse impacts associated with road construction and uporading activities:
* loss of land and other privately-owned assets:
j2               *  adverse impacts on sutbsistence/livelihood or income-earning capacity: and
*  collective adv erse impacts on groups (e.g. through the loss of communal resources and
|                    assets).
To mitigate unforeseen effects on roadside commuinities and promote general upliftment.
3                rehabilitation  and  support measures will be extended  to  include  vulnerable social
cateuories xho may be adverselv affected bv road construction.
i                Entitlemenits are oruanised around categories of loss (e.g. cultivation land. residential
structure. commercial cstablishmcnt) to ensure that persons wvho suffer more than one type
|              ofl loss. receive compenisationi or rehabilitation support for each category of loss.
Nc\\ Ro(it. l)D:velopnicnitand t:pr;rding (ornpoIcnL[                          RAP. PaLe 9



i
Nepal: Road NMainte.nanice and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                          Resettlement Action Plan
Entitlements have been developed accordingT to domestic lecislation and supplemzented.
where necessary. wvith additional measures to comply with World Bank specifications.
Entitlements for land losses 'are in the form  of cash compensation. Throughout Nepal.
cultivation land is at a premiunm  and replacement land is. accordintlv. not readily
available. Areas not under cultivation are generallv not suitable for crop productioni
(because of factors such as slope and poor soil quality). while agricultural resettlement on
uovernment-owned forest land is prohibited. Every- effort will. nevertheless. be made to
pro'ide additional land-based options to households whose production levels are severely
affected by land acquisition. This will primarily be achieved through Local Consu'tative
Forums (LCFs). established at VDC-level to assist with the identification of suitable
privately-owned cultivation land in the vicinity for purchasing by affected households.
The current DoR practice of obtaining land through donations wvill also be allowxed.
provided thaT procedures as laid out in the Entitlement Framework are adhered to. These
include that:
*  affected owners are informaed of their right to compensation for the acqutired land:
*  affected owners and communities participate equally with project authorities in
alignment selection: and
-  each donation is fullN recorded and verified by the donor. DoR and relevant district
and local officials.
For buildinus. as wvell. compensation will be in cash. For fully acquired houses. twNo
approaches will be followed. Displaced houselholds with alternative acconamodationi will
receive a caslh lump sum  payment. Displaced households who do not have altemative
accommodation wvill receive their compensation in two instalnments: an initial payment and
a final payment after the construction  of replacement housing  has successfully
commenced.
Forrmal resettlement planning will be undertaken where more than 10 househlolds fror- the
same settlement/residential area have to be relocated.

As the project authoritN. DoR will assume overall responsibility for the management of
procedures as detailed in the RAP  Key activities that will be undertaken to ensure
effective  implenmentation  of resettlement. compensation  and  rehabilitation  activities
(detailed in Chapters 6 and 7). include:
*  implementationi of procedures to (a) minimise adverse social impacts (acquisition of
land and building acquisition) throughout the plannina. design and implementation
phases and (b) accurately record all project-affected persons. by means of census and
asset verification and quantification exercises. and the issuing of identification cards:
_J
*  establishment of systems and procedures for the co-ordination of resettlement and
compensation activities on the various road sections:
*  establisinmenit of Local Consultative Forums (LCFs) at VDC  level to effectively
address the  social issues  associated  with  the  RMDP. The objectives  of this
participation programme w-ill be to (a) ensure ongoing  dissemination  of project
informationi  to  affected   households  (b)  structure.  regulate  and  strengtheni
communication betwveen roadside communities. DoR  and  its contractors: and (c)
involve affected communities and  local government structures in social impact
j                    mtanalement.- 2rievance  resolution  and  monitoring. thereby  promoting  collective
oruTanisation and decision-makinu:
|  clistribution of copies (in .Xepali) of the approved Entitlement Framework. and follow-
up community meetinsgs to enstire full comprehenision of its contents:

3.0 SOCIAL IMPACTS
3.1      INTRODUCTION
Nepal is one of the poorest countries in the wvorld. xvith up to -45% of its population
defined as poor (HMG/N. 1996b; UNDP 1998: 126). Although a national phenomenon.
there are nevertheless differences in the incidenc,e of poverty between the country's five
development regions and three ecological zones.5 The most obvious is the higher
incidence of poverty in the rural areas (as muclh as .6 times higher than in urban areas:
UNDP. 1998: 128). Also. the incidence of povertv tends to be highest in the mountain
zone (followved by the hills and Terai zones) and Far-Western and Mid-Westem
Development Regions. Although there is a correlation between poverty and caste/ethnic
(group. these tlhree geographical realities may reduce its importance as a factor in poverty
(i.e. people from  different caste/ethnic groups in a mountain area of the Far Western
Development Region are generally subject to the same structural conditions and mav.
therefore. experience similar levels of absolute and relative poverty).
HIMG/N's Ninth Plan (1997-2002) identifies poverty alleviation as one of the major
government objectives. aiming to reduce the number of people living below the poverty
line to 32% bv the year 2002. This is to be achieved through the creationl of employment
opportunities. human resource development. special attention to disadvantaged groups and
the establishment of a poverty alleviation fund.
This chapter considers key positive and adverse social impacts associated wvith
construction/upgrading  of the RMDP roads. including prospects for general social
development, against the background of current socio-economic conditions in the
concerned development regions and districts.
3.2    REGIONAL, DISTRICT AND VDC PROFILES
3.2.1    Social Development Status
All the roads are situated in the hill zone (i.e. middle and/or high mountain phvsiographic
reQions). wvith the exception of Gorusinge-Sandhik-harka. which runs from  the Terai
through the Siw"alik ranue to the hill region. Three of the RMDP roads are situated in the
Far-Western Development Region (FWDR). four in the Mid-Wv'estern Development
Region (M%'DR) and one in the Western Development Region (WDR). The roads cross
11 districts. 'while a further seven ma- benefit from  improved access created by road
construction and upgradingU.
Nepal is demarcated into five development regions. lhese run from east to west and each region therefore
encompasses the three major ecological zones of the country (i.e. Mountains. Hills and Terai).
Neo Road DCcsclopment und UJpgrading C'omiponicnit                      RAP. PaLe 13



Nepal: Road Maintenanice and Developmiient Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                                   Resettlement Action Plan
Table 4: Road Districts and Potentially Influenced Districts

Numerous studies have been undertaken to assess the social development status of NepalVs
development regions and districts. all of which point to the underdeveloped nature of the
mountain/lhill areas tn L7eneral and the MWDR and FWDR in particular. One of the most
recent. undertaken by ICIMOD  in  1997. rates Nepal's 75 districts according to 39
development indicators. broadly categorised as follovs:
*   povert% and deprivation:
*   socio-economic. institutional and infrastructure development:
*   women's empow-erment: and
*   natural resource endownment and manauement                                                               I
The k-ey dev.elopment indicators and ratin-s from  the ICI?\MOD  study are sumnmarised in
Table 6. This shows that five of the I I road districts are amonost thle 10 %vorst-perform,ing<1
districts. Achham  District is rated as the worst performing- district in the country. closely
followed by Kalikot. Jumla. Bajura. Dailekh and Jajarkot Districts.

The recently published Huiman Development ReporL (UNDP. 1998). which groups the
countrv's districts acc*ording to a Humani Development Index (HDI). arriv-es at similar
coniclusions. The HDI consists of thiree human components:
*0 longeviny (.as a proxy for healthi-related capabilities),
*   edcazcction (as a proxy for knowledge anid information-related capabilities): and
*   incoine (as a proxy for capabilities to acquire a particular level of li-ving) (UNDP.
1~~~~ ~1 998:33).
The 1 906 HDI valUe of 0.378 for the country indicates ani overall low level of iunman
development (1 .0 being the highest level of huiman development). Two of the road districts
(Kalikot and Baj'ura) are placed in a gyroup of three districts with the lowvest HDI (less than
0.2). and seven (Jajarkot. Jumla. Dailekh. Salvan. Achiham. Darchula and Kapilbastu) in
the group of districts with the second lowest H'DI (0.2 - 03 3)6

Table 10 lists kev demograplhic features of the population recorded in the sample survey.
A total of 1.558 persons ,vere recorded in the 197 new road households. and 1.23 1 in the
213 upgrading road households. The average household size for the new road households
is considerably higher than the national average (7.9 persons: minimum of one- maximum
of 24). while that of the houselholds along the upgrading roads is only slightly higher than
the national av erage (5.8: minimum of two. maximum 22).
I                Households predominantly consist of nuclear families (68.7%  of the household population
for new roads and 78.5%  for upgrading roads) and other relatives such as grand-children.
daughters-in-law% and parents (26.5% new roads. I S.2% upgrading roads).
For bolh samples. the age cohort 15 years and younger constitute about 42% of the
houschold population. while the potentiallv economicallv active population (16-65 vears)
varies between respectively 54.7% and 56.3% for the new and upgrading road samples.

Settlement patterns in the project areas generally reflect the distribution of arable land and
the development of market areas alongT trade routes. AccordingTly. most of the areas exhibit
a scattered settlement pattem. interspersed  by a number of large settlements and
bazaars.'marKet places. Apart fronm their trading role. the larger settlements often have
important administrative and service functions.
The primary hill/mountain centres in the concerned Development Re-gions are the
municipalities of Birendranagar (Surkhet District). Dipaval (Doti District). Amargadhi
(Dadeldhura District). Jumla (Jumnla District) and other district headquarters suchi as
Salavan and Dailekh. The larger urban centres of NepalguLn'. Dliangadhi. N'Iahendranagar           I
and Butwval are located in the Terai. outside of the identified impact districts. These toxvns
nevertheless are "critical junctures for trade and conimerce. functionii^n as eatewaVs into
the Himalavan hills and mounltain zones (Allan. 1998).
Miaration from the hill areas to the Terai (lowlands) is a common demographic feature in
many hill/mountain districts. reflecting people's desire to gain access to agricultural land.
services and trade and emplovntent opportunities. Gurung's (1998) analysis of census
information shows thtat 86.2% of the out-migrants (i.e. place of enLmLerationi different from      j
place of birth) reported in the 1991 census. originated in the mountain and hill zones. Out-
migration from the hill zone constituted 72% of total internal mieration. up bv 10.7% from
the 1981 census. Out-mi_ration front the more remote mountain zone. on the otlher ltand.
decreased fronm 30.3%  in 1981 to 4.2% in 1991. This decrease is partly related to the fact
tihat the government practice of promoting and sanctioning settlement oni forest land in the
Terai was discouraged front about 1980 and officially prohibited by 1985. The continued
movement of hill people to the Teral. howvever. reflects the more direct econonic. social
and cultural links between the hill and Terai zones.
Regions w\ith tihe highest levels of out-nigration are the Eastern and Western Hills.

3.2.3       Economic Activities and Subsistence
The economy of Nepal revolves around subsistence agriculture. with a small percentage of
the population formally employed outside the agricultural sector. Table 13 summarises the
occupationial status of the population  (1991) older than  10 vears in the road  districts.
showing thiat the vast majority  of the population  is recorded in the farming/agricultural
sector.

Notwithstandin-t the countrv's subsistence atericultUral orientation. less than 20%  of the
total land area comprises cultivation land. Accordingly. most household landholdings are
small (69%?o are smaller than I ha and 89% are smaller than 2 ha). and the national average
landholding size is onlN 0.24 ha (HMG/N. 1993: UNDP. 1998). W'ith the exception of a
hi-her national average. the Nepal Living Standards Survey (11IMGN. 1996b) recorded
similar landholding) sizes for a sample of 3.3 73 households:                                         |

The study also reveals the skewved distribution of land ownership. In the hill area. for
example. approximately 7% of the sampled households own/operate landholdings of 2 ha
or larger. constitutinu 36% of the total reported hill cultivation area. In the 'I'erai. the 20%
largest landowners occupv more than 55%o of the cultivation .area. (HMG/N. 1996b). These
statistics imply that large numbers ol' housellds have marginal landholdings (less than               I
0.5 ha) that are insufficient for houseChold subsistence.
Table I 5 showxs the number of registered landholdings and combined landholding- area for 
the road districts for 1991. For most of the new road districts. tihe average landholding size
is approximately 0.64 ha. with the exception of Achhani (0.28 ha) and Kaliklot (0.38 ha).
A%era-e  landholdinc  sizes  in  the  districts  crossedl by  the  upgrading  roads  varv
considerablv. from  1.76 ha for the Terai district of Kapilbastu. to 0.38 ha for the hill
districts olf Dailekl and Kalikot.

The dominant form  of land tenure is simple freehold (rcaikar,). Cultivation land is
re_istered in terms of the Lal Acit 2021 (and amendments). Ovners are issued land
- 4           certificates (il puija) and details are retained at district Land Survey and Land Revenue
Offices. alongc with cadastral maps. The land allocated to the ori_inal landowner is mostlv
inherited wvithin the family. althougLh land transactionis between non-related persons do
occur. Frau7mentation of landholdings is common. w-ith household iandholdings often
consisting of a numnber of dispersed land parcels.

household landholdin!e size of 1 .35 ha was recorded. However. as shownii in Table 16. this
averace tends to conceal the range of landholding sizes reported by households. For
instaince. the 22 landholders wvith reported holdings larger than 2.5 ha. constitute only
13.5% of th,e sample but ow -n 36% of the total reported landholdings. On the other hiand.
the 3'1 landholders wvith holdinos ot 0.5i ha or smaller,. make up 220% of the sample. but
ow -n onlk 4% of the total landholdings.
A  considerablv smaller avcrage household landholding  (1.06 ha) was recorded for
upgrading, roads. Consequently. the numiiber of 'households with landholdings of 0.5 ha and
|              smaller. is more than for the neN\ road sample (33.8%). These households own onlv 8.4%'
of the total reported landholdings. while the top 7.5%i'o (i.e. wvith landholdings larger than
2.5 ha) o,n '.1 %.

AlthougJh private owvnership is the dominant form of land tenure (approximately 85%/o of
cultivated land is owvner-operated: UNDP. 1998). other forms of tenure occur. These
include tenanc. n7te or1 ban7daki (essentially an informal loan svstem  withi the land
parcels held as suretv by the money lender) and share-cropping. Low castes groups such1 as
the Kan7i (iron smith). Dcnami (tailor) and Scrki (shoemaaker) are often landless or margzinal
landholders wvho depend for their subsistence on other landownlers.
Slaverv wvas officially abolishied in Nepal in 1924. yet the system  of bonded labour
(kanutiva) still prevails in the mid- and far-western Terai. According to officials figures
there are approximately 15.000 kcrnyciia households in the country. mainlv in the far-
western Terai districts (Kathmandu Post. 24/11/98). Debt-bonded agricultural labourers
(haliva.s). mostly from low caste groups. are also found in the mid-vestern and far-western
hills (LTNDP. 1998: 1 10-1 I l).
Cereals are the dominant crops and includes rice. maize. wvheat. millet and barely. Other
crops include lentil. mustard. and potato. Apple farming is also practised in Jumla District
and parts of Kalikot District. Othier fruits include oranges. lemon and bananas.
Livestock- raisinu- is the second  most important production  activity  after croppinsg.
Livestock provide meat. millk. eggs and a cash income. Large livestock are also an integral
part of cropping- activities. providingL drautght power and producing orsanic fertiliser.
Li-vestockn most commonly held are cattle. w-ater buffalo. goats and sheep. The large
majoritv (93.4%) of households in the new,- road sample ownv livestock. For the upgrading1
sample. livestock ownership is considerably less (63.8).

for rural areas (HMG/\. 1996b). Within the rural areas. the incidence of poverty is higher
U               in the hills than in the Terai. and more concentrated in the western parts (HMG/N. 1997e).

3.2.4       Kev Social Services and Facilities
]            ~~~~~3.2.4.1    Eduicationi
The educational statuis of Nepal's citizenis hias inicreased progressively sinlce thle
imiplemenitation of the National Educational System in 1971. For example. thle literacv r-ate
of persons older than six y'ears increased fromi approximately 15% in 1 971 to ncarly 40%
in 1996. the number of primary schools increased firom  7.634 to 2 1.473. lo-w~er-secondarv
Nc~% RoaLl De~ elopmerit andi Upgrading Componenit                                           RAP. Patee 25



Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                                     Resettleiment Action Plan
schools fronl 677 to 5.041 and secondary schools from  494 to 2.654. Nonetheless, there
are disparities between different reizions and social categories with respect to access to
basic educational facilities and literacv rates remain low: 31 .3 I for the FWDR in 1996 and
31.89 for the NTWDR. The WA/DR. on the other lhand. had the highest rate of all the
development regions, namely 44.47 (UNDP. 1998: 77. 80. 82-83).
Although primary school enrolment in the country nearly doubled betwveen 1984 and 1994.
drop-out and repetition rates are high. resultillO in lo\w  promotion rates. Based on  1 994
promotion rates. it is expected that 63°  of thie total primary; students enrolled in 1994 will
not complete their primarn  school education  (LNDP. 1998: 78). As a result. cross
enrolmenit rates  for lower secondarv  and  secondary  schools  decrease  si'nificantlv
(HMG/N. 1996b).
This high student drop-out rate is attributed to the followino:
* household wvork burden of children:-
* iiTeoularity of school operation:
* household income poverty:
* physical distances to schools:
*   lowv perceived relevance of education: and
*   caste/ethnic discrimination: neglect of mother-tong'ue in school (UNDP, 1998: 79-80).
Gross enrolmiient rates recorded in the NLS Survey show that primarv school attendance is
higJhest in the WDR. followed by the Eastern Development Region. the MWDR and the
FWDR (HNIGN. 1996b).
Tables 22 summarises educational facilities and student enrolment for the road districts.
These figures show- that the districts suffer from  inadequate secondary  and tertiarv
educational facilities in particular. Jumla and Jajarkot Districts, for example. had less than
1I0 secondary schools in 1996. and secondary school students comprised less than 5% of
the total student population. The same pattern is evident for the other districts, with the
possible exception of Argyhak-hachi. Surklhet and Kapilbastu Districts.

3.2.4.2    Health
The average life expectancy in INepal was estimated at 5_5  ears in 1 994. This represents
an increase of some 13.5 v'ears in life expectancy between 1976-1996. Factors contributing
to this increase are hig-her rates of innLIllisation and improved control over- epidemics
such as cholera. smallpox. measles and malaria (U-NDP. 1998: 57). Nevertheless. life
-*               expectarncv remains low. particularly in mountain aned rural areas. Coontributing factors
include: (a) limited access to health facilities: (b) low level and quality of nutrition: and (c)
sanitation problems (IJNDP. 1998: 56-57).
Table 24 _ives and indication of the problems that people in the road districts experience
with regard to access to health facilities. All the districts have very fewn hospitals. health
centers and primary health centers. AccordinlIv. people mainly rely on health posts and
health sub-posts that are often inadequately staffed and experienced to deal wvith thc full
range of health issues and cases.

3.3    SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT POTENTIAL
HMG/lN\'s Ei-ht Plan (1992-1997). as wvell as the Agricultural Perspective Plan. emphasise
the importance of rural road linkages in the development process. The lack of appropriate
levels of infrastructure (of which rural roads are a key component) is seen as a major
impediment to community development. The rural population. in particular. is restricted
from participating in economic groxwth. because of inadequate access to health. education.
transport. communication and market facilities. Apart from  the periodic repair and
maintenance of highwavs. the Eight Plan. therefore. proposed the construction of
1.200 km  of rural roads. 125 km of main tracks and 830 kIm of mule trails (1-,1G/N'
1997e) As a component of this infrastructure developnment programme. the RMDP.
particularlv the new  r oad section. is anticipated to aid the Government's poverty
alleviation efforts as detailed in the 'Ninth Plan.
This emplhasis on the role of roads in e'conomic gyrowtlh and poverty alleviation hicihlights
the fact that roads create opportunities for development: for example. by stimulating newv
or enhanced income-cenerating opportuLnities. These indirect impacts are often miuch more
siunificant than the direct impacts catused during road constructioll (e.(. land acquisition
and constl-uction employment opportunities). since they may induce enduring socio-
economlic chan,ces.                                                                            1
The positive reaction of roadside communities and district officials to road construiction.
underscores the importance attached to these indirect impacts. It was frequent]y stated. for
example. that the roads would improve access to market areas. lead to a reduction in the
cost of imported household Ooods (consumer items). create opportunities for the export of
crops and stimulate local development. Their support of the project does not implv a lackL
of concerni over property losses (the effect of land losses in particular). but a belief that the
development potential associated with the roads outweighs direct adverse impacts.
These indirect impacts. as Xwell as road construction employment opportunities. are briefly
considered in this section. followin2- which the key direct impacts (e.g. land losses) are
presented in Section 3.4. Given the lkev features of the socio-economic environment. as
described in the preVious section. the followine indirect impacts may result fi-om road
constructionl:
*  potential for hiuman development through an improvement in access to essential               |
services:
*  new or adjusted economic opportuniities wN-ithin the agricultUral and off-farm sectors:
*  changes to population distribution and settlemenit patterns.
3.3.1    Potential for Human Development
Thlie first of these impacts is fairly clear: thie new roads are anticipated to improve general
mobilit\ and access for an estimated population of 124.3 14 in the road VDCs. and nearly
370.000 in the roads' w\ider zones of influence (HMG/N. 1998c). For people in close
NL'\\ Ruild DL )ccopnicnrt and l;pcr.iin* component                       RAP. Page 2S



Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                         Resettlement Action Plan
proximity to the roads. this benefit is considerable. Consequently. nearly all the
respondents (96.4%) interviewed along the new roads believed their living standards
would be improved. through the improvement of access to market centres and towns in the
Terai. health facilities and schools. More distantly-located people. too. will benefit from
the new roads. since their journev time to services and opportunities in the Terai and
elsewhere. while remaining high. will nevertheless be significantly reduced.
Substantive increases in levels of human development depend not only on improved
access to existing facilities, but also on accompanving developments in the non-road
sector (e.. increases in the number of health facilities and schools). 'hile it is difficult to
separate road-induced impacts from other regional/national development efforts. evidence
from other hill/moLntain roads, nevertheless. suggzests that roads do have a development
effect. Earlier reports on the impacts of the Lamosangu-Jiri Road Project (LJRP) and the
multi-focused Integrated Hill Development Project (IHDP). for instance. did not observe
sigznificant differences between national improvements in socio-economic indicators and
those recorded in the project area (SDC. 1990; 1991). Four vears later. though. the final
monitoring report found that people in the area considered the road to hlave "induced more
lasting and relevant changes than the IHDP.' It has opened up the area. stimulated the
creation of new  business opportunities and reduced the prices of imported goods.
Accordin-la. "manv of the rnega-trends observed in the development of the regional
economv can be attributed to the road" (SDC. 1995). This conclusion underscores the fact
that development projects such as the IHDP are interventions that rely on continued effort.
I              and are olten constrained frorr. serving more than a selected number of beneficiaries. In
contrast. roads are more or less permanent. and their primary benefits (increased access
]3             and mobility) are available to a wide pool of people.
The LJRP-IHDP reports. along with other studies (HMG/N. 1995: 1996c; 1998d). note the
social development effects associated with improved access and mobility. Since the new
road sections are situated in the two most underdeveloped regions of Nepal. the RMDP is
- l            expected to contribute in a similar manner to:
*  an improvement in food supply and a reduction in the cost of consumer items:
*            *  an improvement in the overall health status of people and a reduction in child mortalitv
LJ                rates. through improved access to health facilities. counseling and informationi:
*  possible increases in literacv rates through improved access to education:
*  an improvement in the position of vulnerable social categories and groups. through the
creation and stimulation of income-generating opportunities and a reduction in social
3                 and economic disparities.
TF'he literature also points to a range of other socio-cultural effects (both positive and
neizative) that ma! result from improved access. particularlv to previously isolated areas.
For instance. it was postulated that the Arun Ill access road inlto the remote Arun valley
3             may lead to an erosion in traditional values. the displacement of traditional crafts due to an
influx of consumer products. more substantive houses (with greater use of non-traditional
materials) and changes in the physical form  and social patterns of settlements (NEA.
Nc\% Road Dc eonment andi UpQrading Component                           RAP. Page 29



Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                             Resettlement Action Plan
1993). The LJRP-I14DP monitoring reports found that younger people in the projecl area
strive for an urban lifesty-le. that wvomzen from poorer households increasinglv assume farm
management responsibilities while their husbands migrate in search of seasonal work. and
that labour shortages and access to new economic opportunities are leadino to a shift 'in
occupational patterns across caste/etlhnic lines (SDC. 1991: 1995). The group discussions
show- that people are aware of these types of effects. For exanmple. it wvas stated that the
roads Would:l
*  increase the incidenice of thleft and other crimes:
*  tranSmitl o-tside' cultLiral practices and fashions to the roadside settlements:
* attract the Voung (generation to "outside>'urban areas.
Manv of these chanoes are occurring across N'epal. as the country becomes more
inteurated with tlle *modern' world. Somze may be considered as positive changes. otlhers
negative. All of them  will probably be accelerated by the ncev roads. particularly in the
more isolated districts located in the FWDR.
3.3.2     Economic Stimulation and Adjustment
The roads may stimulate or induce adjustments in (a) local agricultural production and (b)
off-farmii incomne-earning activities and opportunities. The group discussions elicited many
responses about the potential effects of the roads on local economic activities. For         
example. it was stated thai the roads wouLld:
*  provide easier access to agricultural inputs (e.g. fertiliser and seeds):
* create opportunities for the export of agricultural and livestock products:
* creatc opportunities for the establishment of local businesses:
* attract people from outside the area to start laroe-scale businesses;
* reduce the use of porters and other providers of non-vehicular transport:
*  impel porters and other existing transport providers to sell their services in other areas
of the district. or to sLIpplement their livelihoods with other forms of income-
gcneration:
*  reduce the cUltivation production levels of houiselholds whose land is acquired:
*  increase land prices along the road and at market areas:
*  attract "outsiders' to buy land in the area (local people may sell their land and become
poor):
*  lead to snmugg(ling of medicinal plants from the area.
In the road districts. wihere subsistenlce auriculture is the dominiant activit\. production
increases could be expected for the range of subsistence crops. as may diversification to
l
NcE\ Rlaii  l)Cl~onmn>It und I p:rjrdin< C>irpmlwnt                         RAP. Pace 30



Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                            Resettlement Action Plan
higher value crops.l1 Other studies confirm  that roads may lead to these production
increases and changes. For instance. construction of the Arun III access road was expected
to provide access to southern markets for hill products. specifically livestock products and
cardamom  (NEA. 1993). Reference is made in RNIDP lnterim  Report No.1 to the
diversification to higher value export crops that occurred after construction of Ilam-Fikkal-
Charali and Fikkal-Pashupatinauar roads.
However. these changres are not necessary automatic. nor do they occur in a short period of
-,              time. The Lamosaneu-Jiri road studies- for example. found that. apart from the export of
seed potatoes. there had been no 'major export trend observable since the road opened."
T'here had been considerable production increases in the project area in the period between
1975-1995. similar to increases reported for other hill areas. These increases were
considered to be the result of 'many small chanoes in the aaricultural sy stem." an
important one beino the introduction of chemical fertiliser folloxwina the opening of the
road. While production of potato and oran-es had increased substantially. that of other
staple crops had apparently stagnated. (SDC. 1995).
A  profit-maximising response to new  and enhanced commercial opportunities in thle
aEricultural sector is. therefore. not necessarilv automatic. It is more likely vwhere there
alreadv is an established commercial agricultural sector. together with associated credit
services. input supplies and marketina arrangements. Additionally. subsistence farmers
may (understandablv) be averse to diverting resources awav from  a klnown and secure
I               'form of farming practice to a commercial one wvhich carries considerable risks. Thus.
while the new roads will create the potential for economic diversification. and "xhile
nearly all of the household respondents believed that the roads wvould provide these
opportunities. it may take time for them to be fully realised.
Changes may also be expected in local off-farm economic activities. As perceived by
participants in the group discussions. the roads will create opportunities for the
establishment of small commercial enterprises along the roadside (e.g. stores. shops and
ii             lodges). However. while respondents thought that local people would be able to takc
advantage of this opportunity. there was a concem that --outsiders'- would be attracted to
the area. particularly market areas. to buv up land and start larger businesses.
Participants in the group discussions also stated that the roads would have an effect
(mostly negatively) on the work of porters and other providers of non-vehicular transport.
They were of the opinion that porters and other transport providers Nwould change their
professions. or extend their "areas of operation" to other parts of the road districts. In the
I              household interviews, on the other hand. only some 10% of the respondents felt that road
construction would have an adverse effect on these types of income-earning opportunities.
3              TI his is somewhat contradictory to the relative importance of income from this source as
irecorded in the survey: income from  goods convevinc was recorded for 1 .37%  of the
11households. and had the second highest mean income after wa-es earned in India.
"' Kalikot-Jumia road. for instance. may stimulate an increase in the production and exporr of apples from
Jnumila District.

Nepal: Road Maintenance and DeveloDment Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                          Resettlement Action Plan
Interview-s w-ith a sample of 90 business owners along the road alignments point to the
importance of porters and rented animals for the conveying of consumer goods. Similar
interviews with a sample of 10 owners of commercial establishments located along, the
upgradinu( roads in thle RMDP. s1ow tliat trucks are the dominant form of transport of'
goods to/fromii market centres. but that porters and animals are nevertheless used. This
suaests that roads do have an effect on the work- patterns of porters and other providers of
non-velicular transport. Long haul work may decline. but since the roads will increase the
import of goods into the districts. there may be additional opportunities for porters and
other transport providers to convey goods to off-road settlements. One of the LJRP-IHDP
monitoring reports reaclhed a similar conclusion: porters undertake goods conveying over
shorter distances. but because of increased imports. their work opportunities remain more
or less the samze (SDC. 1990). Nevertheless. it will be necessary to monitor the impact of
the roads on these types of local activities. and provide appropriate support to persons
whose livelihoods have been compr-onmised.
3.3.3    Channges to Population Distribution and Settlemcnt Patterns
The roads may also lead to chanoes in migration and settlement patterns. as well as
population growth rates. in the concerned districts/regions. RMDP Interim Report No. I
anticipated a slight increase (0.25%) over current population grow th projections for all the
new road districts. primarily due to expected reductions in the migration of people tc the
Terai. as well as the possibility of re-mieration to hill areas (HMG/N. 199%c). For
instance. after construction of Dhanghadi-Dadeldhura and Ilam-Fikkal-Charali roads.
people were attracted to the concerned hill districts to take advantage of new  crop
production opportunities (e.(. oranges. tea and cardamom). The report on the' Lamosangu-
Jiri road and Integrated Hill Development Project (IHDP). on the other hand. notes that
notwithstanding evidence of tlhe return of some migrants to Dolakha and Sindhupalchok
Districts. "tle continued population growth and the slow growth of off-farm employment
force people to migrate ... there is a loss of 'human capital."' (SDC. 1995).
Populationi grownth is inflUlnced byv a number of variables. and it is difficult to predict what
effect the roads may have on grow-th rates. Improved access to health services and family
plannino programmes may affect fertility and mortality rates. and stabilise grow-th rates in
the long-term. Migrationi patterns may be affected. Improved access to the Terai may
increase both seasonial labour migration and permanent migration. Or it may attract out-
migrants and other sectors ol' the population to the newly opened areas. While it is highly
lilkely that sonie out-migrants who have harnessed sutfficient funds and skills may return to
exploit new oppolrunities. thle overall effect. as noted for the Lamosangu-Jiri road. is
likely to be an increase in out-Migration.
Populationi redistribution may also occur w-ithin the road districts and VDCs. as people are
attracted to the road corridors to exploit opportunities. Existing market areas proximate to
the roads (e.. N1ainma and Tatopani on Kalik-ot-Jumla. Manualsen onl Sanfebauar-
Manualsen arid Martadi on Sanifeba-ar-Martadi) are likely to expand. New market areas
I

Nepal. Road Maintenance and Development Project
