and population concentrations are likely to occur at intersections -with major trails.'1
J             However. a major movement of people from the road districts and VIDCs towards the road
corridors is not anticipated. as confirrmed by current settlement patterns alongz the
juprading roads in the RMIDP.
3.3.4     Road Construction Employment
Access to construction employment opportunities is often regarded as an important (albeit
short-term) beneficial impact associated with a deve]opment. This sentiment is shared. not
only by government and development agTencies. but also by affected communities.
On large-scale projects wvith siginificant local impacts and large numbers of construction
jobs (e.g. hydroelectric projects). the employment of local work-ers is often a sensitive
issue. 2 In the road sector. however. construction is generallv undertaken through the
annual allocation of small contracts (e.g. 1-2 km road sections) and it may take a number
of years to complete a short road. This implies a relatively small construction labour force
per contract. in contrast to. for instance. the Arun road project. where it was estimated that
the road contractor would employ a labour force of more than 6.700 durin- peak dry
seasons. Access to construction emplovment opportunities. while not nearlv at these
levels- is nevertheless a potentially important beneficial impact.
The maximisation of local participation in road construction and maintenance should be
encouracged. From  discussions with a sample of contractors (summarised below), thie
biggest constraint to achieving this aim appears to be the unavailability/irregular supply of
local workers resultin- from  agricultural obligations. Cultivation  is a kev factor in
household survival. and agricultural work therefore takes precedence in decisions abouLt
the allocation of household labour. However. because subsistence agriculture is seldom
sufficient for household survival. people also seek other income-earning opportunities
during, the slack season. During these periods. the employment-seeking decisions of
people (men. mostlv) are influenced by the returns they expect to get from their efforts. As
opposed to potential work on road contracts that are awarded accordingy to the availability
of government funds. seasonal migration to the Terai and India probably offers the best
chance of earnin- a cash income.
Responses obtained from the household interviews would seem to suggest indifference to
5               emplovment on road projects. However. the group discussions show that rather than being2
unwilling to work on road construction. people are concerned about wvaoe rates offered by
contractors. It was commonly stated that people w-ill be prepared to work on the
a               construction if they are paid fair wages. In a fev settlements participants indicatcd their
xvillin2ness to work voluntarily on the project.
Temporary markets may also develop at the road head during the constrLIction period.
For exaample. protests and disruptions occurred at Kali Gandaki 'A   in 1 p998. ilVer- /il over the reported
mismanauement ot employment procedures.
Nc\~ R01ad Development and UJpgrading Componlnt                              RAP. Paue 33



Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Final Report: \'olume 8                                           Resertlemnent Action Plan
All of' the contractors interviewed (cateaories A-D) indicated that thev emplov. or are
willin to employ. local labourers on construction projects. They highlig-hted a ranoe of
benefits associated vith the employment of local labour. An important obligation is the
creation of income-earning opportunities for local people: "to provide employment to local
w-orkers- (i.e. from the project area and other districts) was a fairlv commzon statement.
The perceived benefits of employing, local labourers often revolved arounld the advantage
f!or the company:
*  It is not necessary to provide accommiioodation for local labourers.
*  It is easy to emplov and la! off local labour.
*  It is not necessary to provide advance payxments to local labourers.
*  Local labour is sometimes cheaper than foreign labour.
*  Local labourers are used to the hard conditions in the mountains.
The employment of local labour iniaproves community acccptance of the project and
creates a feeling of ow nership.
Local persons are invariably employed in unskilled job categories. although some
conitractors stated that jobs like office clerks. supervisors and carpenters are filled by local
persons. Nevertheless. skilled wvork is generally reserved for foreign workers. or persons
permanently employed by the contractor. All the contractors stated that local persons are
generally happy and wxilling to xvorkl on road construction projects. No formal recruitment
procedures are used. other than direct contact with local leaders (e.gy. Ward Chairmen) and
communities. Contractors use various employment contract procedures: some stated that
local persons are employed on a contract basis. which includes stating the period of
employment and the rate of payment. Otlhers indicated that workers are oruanised in
groups of' betxveen 10 - 20 to complete a task-. wvith a single amount of money paid to the
(group to distribute amongst themselves.
T'he problems and constraints associated with the employment of local persons were also
raised by contractors. The most frequentlv raised problem wVas that local Workers are not
available on a regular basis because of agyricultural commitments. Other problems
experienced (some of which contradict the perceived benefits) included the following:
*  ILocal workers demand more money than foreiun workers.
*  Local workers are more difficLilt to nmanage (C.g. absent Without notice and strikes).
*  Local persons lack, construction skills.
Some contractors also stated that the employment of local and foreign labour on a single          I
project occasionally leads to difficulties. Quanrels somletimiies occur. either because of
cultural div-isions or differenices in the employment contracts oft local and foreign labour
(e.g. local workers being paid on an attendance basis and foreign labourers on a monthlV
contr-act basis).
N4c\ RK(ad D)\ ci)pnicn naind I p2rauding C!onIlpo)iclit                    RAP. PaLe 34



Nepal: Road Ma7ntenancc and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                         Resettlement Action Plan
Finallv. three international oryanisations were asked to share the experience they have
goained in orpanising and fundinga community-based road construction projects in Nepal
(GTZ. Care Nepal and Helvetas). All of them highly recommended the employment of
local persons. statintg that it creates local income-generating opportLunities. helps to
overcome food deficiencies. contributes to poverty-alleviation and promotes skills
-]            development. On none of the road projects finded by these organisation have loreiuln
workers been employed.
-*             Workers are generally appointed on a contract basis and paid according to district rates.
__J           There is no discrimination in the employment of men and wonmen (although physically
strenuous work- can often only be done bv men). nor in wages paid to them. Short on-the-
job  traininu  courses are often provided. while cormmunitv involvement in road
maintenance is encourag-ed through District and Village Development Committees and the
71            establislment of local road user groups/committees.
While projects funded by the three organisation focus on communitv involvement. some
constraints in the emplovnment of local workers where nevertheless noted. As with
contractors. the most important of these relate to the unavailability of local persons durintg
key agricultural periods (i.e. planting and harvestingz). Apart from aaricultural work. other
obligations (e.g. festivals) may lead to irregular work attendance and interruptions of
construction schedules. However. if properly planned and monitored. there is no
sie nificant disadvantage in employing local workers.
3.4      ASSET LOSSES ON NEW ROAD SECTIONS
As stated in Chapter Two. given the context of local subsistence farming practices. the
acquisition of land within a ROW' as specified in DoR design standards, will have far-
reaching effects on roadside households and communities. A basic principle to be adopted
by the project is. therefore. to limit land acquisition and population displacement on newv
roads to an initial ROW  of 15 m (except where a wider area is required for construction
purposes).
J
This section summarises the direct impacts associated w%ith the new road sections under
the followMin headings:
l loss of buildings and structures:
3             *  loss of cultivation land and other natural resources:
* population displacement.

indicated in Chapter One. a census and verification of potentially affected persons and
j            assets has been completed for most of the new road sections. and is currently underwav for
the remainin2 sections. T he information sources for this assessment is:

The Entitlement Framework established for the RMDP makles provision for the payment
of cultivation disruption allowances to households whose production levels are severely
affected by land acquisition. With respect to land losses. a severelv affected project family
(SPAF) is defined as: a household from  wlhom  land acquisition exceeds 25%  of its total
landholdinQs. in the case of landholding!s larger than  0.25  ha. or 10%  of its total
landholdinos. in the case of landholdings of 0.25 ha or smaller. or where land losses lead
to the remaining lanidholding not being economically viable (as identified through the
participatory application of context-specific criteria: see C'hapter Five).
DurinLg the census exercise. it xwas possible to verify the total landholding size of 257 of
the 300 affected owners. Table 30 shows iltat 13 of these 257 owxners have holdinas of
0.25 ha or smaller. Of these. nine will lose more than 10%  of their total landholdinLs. thus
qualifyine for t:ae allow-ance described above. Onl- I3 ouf the landowx-ners wVith holdinTs
larger than 0.25 ha are expected to be severely affected by land losses.

3.4.4.4    Estimate of Asset Losses on Renmainiiig Road Section (165+001 to 220+44(Li
The initial portion of the Kalikot-Jumla alignment passes through steep and rocky forested
terrain. and impacts on private assets are therefore relatively insi_nificant. The terrain
iradually becomes less steep and the alignment finally enters the Jumla vallev. Social
impacts on the remaining road section are. consequently. anticipated to be more significant
than on the portion where the census and asset verification have already been completed.
Thie initial socio-economic survev and asset recording, exercise confirms this. Table 58
summarises anticipated building and land losses as recorded during this initial survey. This
shows that up to 63 residential buildings and 100 commercial enterprises mav have to be
relocated. VDCs where population displacement may be significant are Tatopani and
j               Lamra. A significant number of commercial establishments max' also have to be relocated
in Phui Nlahadev. Kundari. Tatopani and Lamra VDCs.

3.5    ASSET LOSSES ON UPGRADING ROAD SECTIONS
Given the context of local subsistence farming practices. the acquisition of land wA ithin a
ROW  as specified in DoR design standards (30-40 n). will have far-reachine effects on
roadside lhouseholds and communities. A basic principle to be adopted by the project is.
therefore. to minimise land acquisition as far as possible. Accordingly. the corridor of
impact (COI) on the upgrading road sections is defined as the road formation plus a safetv
zone \\here necessary. Asset acquisition vwill only take place wlhere required for upgrading
purposes (e.g. road widening and reali(gnmllent) or safety reasons. It is anticipated that this
COT will vary (accordino to topography and upgrading requiremiienits) betw-een 6 n-, and
9 m.
This section discusses potential direct impacts associated witih road upgrading under the
follow-inze headin(s:i
*  loss of buildings and structures:
* loss of cultivation land and other natural resources:
* population displacement.

3.5.1.3   Population Displacemenit
The results of the census survey (up to klm  35) show  that property acquisition for
upgrading of Surkhet-Kalikot road is fairly insignificant: 10 owners will lose buildings

3.5.2      Dharapani-Chhedegad
]                 Infonnation in this section is based on the initial wvalkover surveys. A census and asset
verification survey is currentlv underway and sclhedtuled for completion by end-July 1999.
The starting point of this upgrading section is Bhurke. a settlement some 214 km  from
Chhinchu in Surkhet District. It ends at Dhaira. 61.5 knm  from  Bhurke. The road followvs
the left banlk of the Bheri River up to Salli Bazaar (45 kin). where it crosses to the right
bank (a terry service operates during the winter and dry months). Most of the road is still
under construction after this crossinel. leavina onlv a few kilometres of motorable road.
Road width varies between 3 mn and 4.5 ni. Engineering, estimates showv that some 6.922 ha
of land will be required for road xvidening.
I The group discussions conducted during the initial fieldw%ork also highlighted people's dissatisfaction w ith
land donated for thle initial road construction still being reListered in their names (i.e. ox ners still liable for
taxes on lanld acquired by the roads). A total of 98 persons have already donated land (up to km 85-00) for
|the initial construction of the road.
'9 Of 32 affected landowners interviexsed up to kim S5. onl1 six ( 190) indicated that their production is
suLfficienit for their annual subsistence requirements, The majority indicated food sufficiency of between four
and six months.

The Dharapani-Chhede!ad census survey (terminated because of potential civil unres; and
securitv problems) is scheduled to be completed by mid-June 1999. It is. consequently. not
possible to give accurate figures pertaining to population displacement. Based on the
initial fieldwork. it is estimated that some 23 households (140 persons) will be displaced
by road upgrading. This represents a significant reduction over the I 5 m COI scenario.
where an estimated 54 additional households (324 persons) would have been displaced.

3.5.3     Gorusinge-Sandhikharka
This road starts at Gorusinoe on the East-WJest Hiuhwav. some 50 km west of Butwal. The
upgrading section starts nine kilometres from Gorusinge. at the v ilfa-e of Birpur. The first
secioi (irprGorusiarn t) e.
two kilometres of the upgradin section (Birpur to Patharlot) is in the Terai. It then passes
through Siwalik hills before endina at Sandhilkharka (the headquarters of Arghakhanchi
District).
The section from Patharkot (knm 2) to'Narapani (km 59) is mostly on an ascending gradient
3              and subject to landslides during the rainv season. The section from  Narapani to
Sandhikharka generally passes througLh stable land areas and experiences few landslides.
Road wvidth is mostly 4.5 m. Encineering estimates show that some 2.080 ha of land will
be required for road wvideninU.
3.5.3.1   Loss of Bu;ildlinigs antd Oflier Strulctu'res
-I            Gorusinge-Sandhikharka is the most heavily populated of the upgrading roads. Major
settlemcnts and market centres include: Patharkot. Chakla. Amarai. Thada. SitapLir.
Narapani. Ghumti. Fudwang and Sandhikliharka.
.J
Because of this population concentration along the road. there is a significant reduction in
building acquisition by limiting land take to actual areas required for upgrading (as
opposed to a 15 ni COI). Table 78 showvs that a total of 69 buildings will be affected by
upgrading. consisting of 65 private buildings and four communitv buildings. Three wvater
3               points \vill also be affected. Thada. Khanchikot and Sitapur are the most heavily affected
VDCs.
' The group discussionis conducted during the initial fieldwork also highlighted people's dissatisfaction wvith
land donated for the initial road construction still being registered in their names (i.e. owners still iiable for
taxes on land acquired by the roads).

3.5.4      Summarv ot Direct Impacts on Upgrading Road Sections
3                 There is little doubt that asset acquisition and population  displacement is significantly
reduced by limiting land take to actual areas required for upgrading works. as opposed to a
-1  m COI. In summarY. the followvinu estimated reduction wxill be achieved:
-   a reduction in the acquisition of private land. from  55.37 ha (if a 15 m  COI had been
established) to approximately 6. 89 ha:
*   a reduction in the acquisition of residential and business structures. from  435 (if a 15
nm  COI had been established) to and estimated  127  actuallv affected bv upgrading
works.
I
]                  22 The group discussions conducted during the initial Fieldwork also highligthied people's dissatisfaction withI
land donated for the initial road construction still bein2 registered in their names (i.e. owners still liable for
taxes on land acquired by the roads). A total of 278 persons donated land for the initial construction of the
road.
Of the 192 affected iando\%ners. tile majority (38.5%) indicated that their agricultural production provides
bctwueen 4-6 months of food sufficienc'. vshile a considerable percentagze (nearly 19°o) indicated food
iil                sufficiency of 3 months or less.

displacement is 51 (less than 9%'o of total households). consisting of some 385 persons. The
additional 5 18 houselholds (3.645 persons) will be affected through the acquisition of land.
commercial establishments and other buildings.

4.0 POLICY AND LEGAL FRAMEWORK
4.1    LEGISLATION
Prior to 1990 there was no constitutionial obligation for the State to pay compensation for
the acquisition of personal property. The right to receive compensation wvas therefore not a
fundamental right. although there w-as a 'moral obligation to pay for whlat vou take'
(Thapa. 1988). Article 17 of the Constitution of the Kingdom of Nepal (1990). however.
establishes the right to property as a fLundamental right. stating that "no person shall be
deprived of his property save in accordance -with the law." The basis of compensation and
the procedures for delivering compensation for any property acquired by the State shall
therefore be as prescribed by the law-.
Land and asset acquisition wvill be undertakeen within the framewvork of the Lcand
-|  ALCquiSiiw7 .4Lct (for permanent land acquisition) and the Piiblic Rocd ALet (for temporarv
land acquisition).
4.1.1     Land Acquisition Act, 203423
(a) The Act empoxvers HMG/N to acquire any land. on the pavment of compensation. for
3                  public purposes and works,
(b) The acquisition and compensation of privately-ownwed assets are undertakien accordingU
to  a formal procedure. consisting  of (a) initial procedures. (b) a preliminarv
investigation process. (c) acquisition notification. (d) compensation notification. and
(e) appeal procedures.
(c) Compensation Determination Committees are established (at district level) to ascertain
compensation rates for land and other assets.
(d) Compensation must be paid (a) for damages caused as a result of investigations during
.- -ithe preliminary investigation process. and (b) for land and assets permanentlv acquired
'1 gbv the project (including, standing crops. trees and houses).
(e) Compensation must be in caslh (lump sum). althouah titleholders who have lost all of
their landholdings may be given replacement land. if available.
(t) Titleholders are reqluired to submit compensationi claims or complaints within a
I                  specified period after the land acquisition notice had been issued by the Local
Authority (Chief District Officer). Compensation for land is paid after determination
]                 of rates and verification of the list of entitled applicants by the CDC.
The 1978 amendmnent of the Puhliu Ruci .4ci vas promulgated to ensure uniformity with the L1Cnd
.4clcqis1io AL.4Ct. It amended Section 4 and repealed Section 5 to 13 of the 1974 Act.
See Annex 16 for further details.
Ne%% RKod l)Decloprcn rnrind l pradinL, Conpontprit                          RAP. Page 69



Nepal: Road Mlvlaintenance and De\elopment Project
Final Report: Volumc 8                                           Resettlemnent Action Plan
4.1.2     Public Road Act, 2031
(a) The Act empowers DoR to acquire anv land on a temporary basis (for storaue
facilities. construction camps. etc.) durinsg road construction and up-gradinu. The
temporary acquisition of land containing any buildin us (e.g(. houses. sheds. temples
and schools) is avoided w-herever possible. The Act also empowvers DoR to lift earth.
stone or sand from any adjoining land" during construction and upgrading w\orks.
(b) The Act does not provide for leasing of land. How-ever. DoR is required to pay
compensation for any damages caused to buildings. crops and trees. where the farmine
activitv of the landowner is interrupted. and where the landowner has to incur
expenses to restore the land afiter its return.
(c) Compensation is determined between DoR and the titleholder. or through mediation.
involving, officials from the relev-ant VpC and District.
(d) HMG/N  may prohibit. through notification in the Nepal Rq/laparra (Government
Gazette). the construction of any permanent stircture (other than walls) within 6 in of
the road limit or edge.
(e) Chapter Four (vet to come into force) empowers HMG/N  to collect a once-ofl'
development tax from owners of land situated up to a distance of 250 m nfrom a newly
constructed road.
4.1.3    Other Relevant Legislation
The provisions of the Land Ac. 2021 (1964) pertaining to the maximum permitted size of'
individual landholdings also apply to land acquisition. since a landowvner may not be
compensated for more land than he is entitled to under the LandAci regulations.
The Land Act additionallv specifies the compensation entitlements of registered tenants on
land sold by the owvner or acquired for development purposes. The provisions of the Ludl
Acquisition Act are in accordance with those of the Land Act of 1964. namelv that a
registered tenant is entitled to 25% of the compensation. However. the fourth amendment
of the Land Act in 1997 increases the tenant's entitlenilt to 50%. This amendmenit was
challengced in the Supreme Court and is currently beine deliberated by a Special Bench of
the Court.
Land acquisition must also complv with the provisions of the GZIhi C'orporuion .4cI, 2023
(1976). Section 42 of this Act states that Guili (religious trust land) acquired for a
development must be replaced xith other land (rather than compelnsated in cash).
NK.o Rjxtd i)cv cioprient and I ipgradinL Corponnilt                      RAP. Page 70



*              tJNepal: Road NMaintenance and Developmenit Proiect
Final Rcport: V olume 8                                         Resettlement Action Plan
4.2    WORLD BANK GUIDELINES
Land acquisition. compensation and resettlemrent will. furthermore. comply wvith World
Bank- Operational Directive 4.30 (being reissued as Operational Policv 4.12 and Bank
Procedure 4.12). dealing with involuntarv resettlement and compensation for losses
associated with development projects.
The overall principle of OD 4.30/OP 4.12 is that project-affected people (PAPs) are
provided with prompt and effective compensation for all losses directlv attributable to the
project. with lost assets Xvalued at full replacement cost. The value of benefits to be derived
from  the project is also not deducted from the valuation of the affected asset. nor is
depreciation of the asset or the value of salvaucn materials.
OD 4.30/OP 4.12 requires that PAPs who lose land are given a range of' options from
which to choose. rather than cash compensation onlyv It recommends replacement land
where losses occur in an agricultural settina. while acknowledoingz that cash payments
may be appropriate "-where the residual landholding of the affected person remains
. l            economically viable."
It also states that a flat rate of cash compensation (based on. or exceeding. local land
market rates) may be paid on linear projects where narrow strips of land are required (e.g.
for road widening) and it is -inefficient to determine the precise replacement cost for each
affected parcel." provided that these land losses do not have a significant effect on
houselhold living standards. To ensure that livinta standards are maintained. this practice is
recommended only wvhere land losses amount to less than 1 0% of any land parcel.
Apart from legal titleholders. 0D4.30/OP 4.12 additionallv specifies the compensation
entitlements of different catetyories of non-titleholders. Those with no leg-al rights at the
time of the census and verification exercise who have a claim  to such rights under
domestic law (e.a. fr'om uninterrupted use of public land with no official eviction orders)
should qualify for the full range of entitlements. provided that "such claims become
recognised under the laws of the country through a process identified in the resettlement
*             plan." Other PAPs xwho occupy land in violation of domestic laws are entitled to
,J             compensation for assets such as buildings and standing crops but not to compensation for
land losses. W'here they have had uninterrupted possession of the land "for at least one
year prior to the commencement of the census. thex are entitled to resettlement assistance
in lieu of compensation for land."
Finally. OD 4.30/OP 4.12 specifies a number of measures to enhance the reestablishment
of' PAPs. l'hese include timely consultation with affected and host communities and
assistance to PAPs during the acquisition. resettlement and reestablishment periods.
Ncx Roadl I)cv'lopmcn anLd t ipgrad inv C(.omponent                      RAP. Page 71



Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project

4.3    LAND ACQUISITION AND TRANSFER
The procedures detailed in the La1n7d,4cquisition7 ct. 2034 form the overall framework for
the acquisition of land and other assets. It specifies the actions and responsibilities of the
agency requiring the land (in this case DoR) and the district government departnment that
will acquire the land (Land Revenue). DoR's responsibilitv is to ensure that the project is
approved by its superior ministry (Works and Transport) and that the reqLIisite initial
studies are undertaken to indicate land areas required. Following completion of these
studies. the process is transferred to the office of the Chief District Officer. whose
responsibility it is to ensure that the required legal and administrative procedures are
followed for acquiring the land.
The procedures in the Act are broadly categorised as follows: (a) Initial Procedures. (b)
Preliminarv Process. (c) Notice of Acquisition. and (d) Compensation Determination and
Eligibility. These are depicted in Figure I and summarised below. The requisite RAP
activities are highliuhted under each procedure.
4.3.1     Initial Procedures
The Department or Agency requiring the land forwards a proposal for acquisition to its
superior Ministry. The proposal must show the location. area of land required. purpose.
and maps. Initial approval can take approximatelv one month.
4.3.2     Preliminarv Process
T-he Preliminary Process starts with the issuing of a notice (within seven days but up to
one month if more than one district is involved) to landowners to inloim  them  of the
preiinminary investigations by the Project Investigation Officer (P1O). The preliminary
investieation can commence three days after the notice had been issued.
The PIO is required to submit a report within 15 days of the issuing of the notice. This
report must contain all pertinent information. as well as details of the extent of damace
caused during the preliminary investiuations and compensation due for these damages.
The process is then transferred to the Local Officer (Chief District Officer). wvho must
arranue for the serving of notices at the principal places of public thorougThfare. at local
settlement offices and on the door of affected houses.

4.3. 3    Notice of Acquisition
The Local Officer is required to prepare a Notice of Acquisition. whlicil inidicates that thic
assets under consideration are to be acquired. The notice must provide details on the tvpe
and location ol' the required properties. Th,e Local Officer must also advises the District
Land Revenue Offices to stop any transactions on the concerned land-
The concerned owners are granted at least 1 5 davs from the issuino of the notice to submit
an application for compensation (with the necessary supportin- documllents). or sevcn days
(excluding travelling time to the district office) to submit a letter of complaint/contest. The
Ministry of Home A'ffairs is norm,nally required to make a decision on a complaint within
1 5 davs. unless further information is required. or unless the complaint has to be solved in
a court of law (e.g. ownership disputes).
The concerned properties can be acquired at any time after the lapse of a period granted
for the lodging of complaints, or after a final decision on a complaint has been made. The
[.ocal Officer must arrange for the transfer of ownership to HMG{N  within 1I5 days of
takina control of the land.

A  Compensation Detenrination Committee (CDC) is established to assess the list of
compensation claims and determine compensation rates for the lost assets. A  list of
entitled persons is prepared and submitted to the Local Officer for publication. Anyone
]                vwho disaurees with the list can register a complaint with the Nlinistrv of Home Affairs
within  15 days of the issuine of the notice. The N4inistrv is required to solve any
complaints wvithin approximately 15 daVs. except for those which have to be resolved in a
court of law.

4.4    VIALUATION AND VERIFICATION OF LOST ASSETS
All assets within the COI will be properlv  recorded  and  verified  by  delegated
representatives from DoR. the relevant District Land Revenue/Survey Office (DLR). the
concerned VDC/Ward and the affected property owner. Census and asset information will
be computerised to monitor the reestablishment of PAPs.
Valuation of assets will be undertak-eni by district-level Compensation Determination
Committees (CDCs). as provided for in the Landc.-icquisition .4c. The CDCs will consist
of:
*  Chief District Officer:
3               *  District Land Revenue Officer:
* District Land Survey Officer:
r :]            *  representatives from the relevant District Development Committee and VDC:
*  representatives from project-affected households,communities: and
*  the DoR Project Chief or his delegated district representative.
\0w ROtid l)cvciopmcnt ain UpiUadiwn- Coniponint                             RAP. Pagc 75



Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                             Resettlement Action Plan
In the determination of compensation rates. the CDCs wvill take account of rates in the
open local market and information gathered during RAP preparation to ensLire th2t
compensation is at replacement value.
4.5   PAYMENT OF COMPENSATION
HMG"N will not takle possession of any private propertv prior to the full payment of
compensation entitlemiients and. where applicable. initiation of relocation arrangements
and economic rehabilitation measures. The project will make every effort to ensuL-e that
displaced households have access to replacement housing prior to their evacuation thlou.ch
payment of a compensation advance and displacement allowances at the time of serving
the notice to vacate. or other formiis of relocation assistance a-reed with the concerned
households.
To ensure transparency of procedures. pavment of compensation will. as far as possible.
be made in the presence of Local Consultative Forum  (LCF) representatives and other
local authlorities. These witnesses will ensure that the affected person understands and
agrees xvith the compensation  amount. and is informed  of the grievance appeal
mechanisms available on the project. Certificates of compensation wvill. in addition. be
issued to each entitled person.
All goernment taxes and duties related to the acquisition and registration of affected
assets will be borne by the project.
4.6    CONSTRAINTS
Since it deals with the acquisition of private assets (some of which wvill lead to the
displacement of households). the RAP has risks and practical uncertainties.
notwithstanding the adoption of principles to guide actions.
In the first place. land acquisition and compensation activities will take place in a large
number of districts. spread across three development regions. This will require effective
co-ordination to ensure adherence to RAP procedures and uniformity of practice. Al the
local level. the required surveys and legal and administrative procedures wvill put
considerable strain on district officials to achieve tar!-et dates. The assets of affected
ow\ners need to be measured and verified by these officials. prior to initiationi ot the
various land acquisition procedures specified in the Lcand.Acclisition .4cl. On the nev road
section. most of the affected househiolds are located at considerable distances trom  tlhe
district offices. and can only be reached on foot. The process of asset verification is clearly
"Oill" to require sufficient time. and has to be comiipleted before commllencemenet of
construction activities.
Ni% Roaud [)Dclopnnet andl tlpgrading LComponent                            RAP. Page 76



Nepal[ Road Maintenance and De\eloprnent ProJect
Final Report: X'olume 8                                            Resettlernent Action Plan
Secondlv. landholding-s are registered in ternms of the Llun  Aci. 2021. Land ownership
details are retained at the District Land RevellUe Offices. along with cadastral maps.
However. Iand owvnership changes. througih inheritance and subdivision. are not alwavs
recorded at the district offices. These discrepancies will undoubtedly complicate tihe
process of identifying and confirming entitled persons.
Thirdlv. because of DoR's current practice of obtaining land through donations. many land
parcels acquired for the inirial construction of roads have not been legally transferred to
HMG/N. As a result. the concerned owners are still liable for annual taxes on the acquired
land. DoR has undertaken to rectifv the matter. b. collecting and forwardingt the names of
these owniers to the relevant district officials. This activity xvill further increase the
workload on DoR and district officials.
Finally. the deliberations over the fourth amendment of the LCu77d .4ct (which increases the
tenant s entitlement to 50%) mar  have an influence on the land acquisition process.

5.0 ENTITLEMENT FRAMEWORK
This Chapter sets out the entitlements approved for the RMDP. It describes:
*  the units of entitlement:
*  entitlements for the loss of private buildin_s:.
*  entitlements for the loss of cultivation and other privately-owvned land:
* entitlements for thie loss of non-perennial and perennial crops:
*  rehabilitation and support measures for severely-affected individuals and households.
A detailed Entitlement Mlatrix is also appended at the end of the Chapter.
5.I       UNIT OF ElNTITLEMENT
Tlhrough the acquisition of private and community assets. the RMDP will affect propertY
owners. their dependants and community groups. The Entitlement Framework accordin-lv
specifies compensation and/or rehabilitation measures for tw o ullits of entitlement: I
individuals (i.e. affected individuals and their househoids) and groups.
5.1.1     Individuals                                                                             i
This cateuorv  includes individuals (men  and women) wkho may  suffer one or a
combination of the folloaine losses:
* loss of cultivation land (titleholders and tenants);
* loss of residential land:
* loss of all or part of residential buildin,, (titleholders. tenants and squatters):
*  Ioss ot'all or part of a commercial building (titleholders. tenants and squatters):
* loss of rented accommodation (tenants): and
* loss of income sources and income-earning capacitv (e.g. porters).
This cateLorv also includes the household members of the person suffering any of thc
above-mentioned losses (i.e. Project Affected Family). For compensatioll amainst the loss
of privately-held  assets  and  resources.  the  unit of entitlement  vill  be  the
titleholder/household head. For rehabilitation assistance. the unit of entitlement w-ill be the
PAF. For exampie. in some cases. houselhold subsistence and survival strategies may be
disrLtpted through the loss of land or business enterprises. In these cases. rehabilita-ion
measures vill be extended to all adult household members to support the re-establishmlTielit
of tlheir formier living standards.
Nc RIoad De\ clopnin( and tipUrad ng Componen                               RAP. Paae 78



Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Proilect
Final Report: Volume 8                                            Resettlement Action Plan
5.1.2     Groups
The project may also have indirect. less-quantifiable or unforeseen effects on people living
inside and in the vicinitv of the road corridor. Positive impacts (such as the potential for
agricultural exports  and  diversification  of local economic  activities) may  occur
spontaneously or require co-operation betwveen different <oovernment sectors. Potential
negative impacts may include a reduction in. or constrained access to. natural resources.
a U            impacts oni water supply and irrigation systems. or changes to local employment practices.
Where these impacts occur. they will be mitigated under the project.
Special attention will be given to social categories and groups -who. because of their social
position. may be vulnerable to the changes brouLht about by the project. or excluded from
its associated benefits.
5.2    HOUSES AND OTHER STRUCTURES
(a) Owners of houses and other structures such as sheds and water mills w-ill be
compensated in cash. for full or partial losses, at replacement cost as determined by thc
CDCs. This wvill include titleholders. tenants and squatters occupyingi public land at the
time of the eligihility czut-off cacte (i.e. census) for each road.
(b) Owners will have the right to salvage materials from the affected buildings. The value
of salvaged materials will not be deducted from the final compensation amount.
(c) Owners (i.e. titleholders. tenants in owvn accommodation. and squatters on public land)
of hoLuses and commercial establishments to be relocated will receive displacement
allowances as described in Section 5.6. Displaced occupants of rented accommodation
wil] receive a rental stipend as described in Section 5.6.
(d) Displaced households and owvners of commercial establishments who own the affected
residential land will be assisted with the identification of suitable replacement
residential or commercial plots in the vicinity. or paid cash compensation  (at
replacement value) for the lost plot.
j
(e) Tenants who have built their own houses on rented land will be assisted wvith the
if                 identification of alternative residential sites in their local communities.
(f) Since this is a linear development. the relocation of largie numbers of households to
newk settlements involving, host communities is not anticipated. However. if this is to
happen. resettlement assistance will be provided to ensure effective integration wvith
host communities and adequate provision of facilities.

.Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                             Resettlement Actionl Plan
(2) Affected community  buildinus and facilities will be repaired  to their previous
condition or replaced in areas identified in conasultation wvith affected comnmunities and
the relevant authiorities. These include schools. temples. hlealth posts. water points.
irrigation canals and footbridoes.
5.3       LAND
-i
(a) Titleholders wvill be compensated tor all permanent land losses at full replacemellt cost.
(b) The current DoR practice of acquiring private land through donationis will be allowed.
provided that:
*  the land  in question1 is free of squatters. encroachers  or other claims or
encumbrances:
-  affected owners and communities participate equally with project autlhorities in
alilnment selection;
*  aff'ected owvners are informed of their ri-ht to compensation for the acquired land:
*  affected owners are not classified as SPAFs:
*  affected owners have recourse to CDCs to raise and have arievances resolved. and
*  the voluntary nature of each donation is fully recorded and verified by the conor.
DoR and relevant district and local officials.
(c) In conformity with current international and local practice. households wvill be
classified according to the percentage of land loss for the determination of entitlements
and rehabilitation assistance. The overall principle will be that titleholders with total
landholdings of 0.25 ha or smaller who lose more than 1 0% of their landlholdingcs. and
titleholders with total landholdingis above 0.25 ha who lose more than 251/% of' their
landholdings. will be classified as SPAFs and entitled to additional rehabilitation
measures.
However. SPAF classification based only on perccntagye land loss, potentially ignores
or simplifies complex socio-economic  processes and  additional context-specific
criteria w-ill be applied in conjunction with local officials and representatives to ftirther
identif- SPAFs. One of the most important is loss of irrigated cultivation, since this
land type play-s an important roie inl houselhold agricultural production. Another is the
size of household landholdings. both before and after land acquisition  Additional
social criteria  to  detemine  severitv  of land  losses  include  the  household's
development cycle and off-faml economic activities.
*  Titlelholders w-ho lose less than 10°h (landholdinu,s of 0.25 ha or less). or  ',°C
(landholding-s larger than 0.25 ha) of their total landholdings. or whose production
levels are not severely affected  by the loss of land. will be offered cash
compensation, payable at the timc of' land acquisition.
Ncsx RodILI Dcvelopment aid lUpgrading Cornpon^.t                          RAP. Pagc 80



a
Nepal: Road Milaintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                            Resettlement Action Plan
*  Titleholders wh]7o lose more than 10%  (landholdings of 0.25 ha or less). or 25%"
*(landholdings larer than 0.25 ha) of their total landholdiinos. or whose production
levels are severely affected by! the loss of land. wvill be offered a choice of
assistance with the identification and purchasino of replacement land. or cash
compensation. Additionally. they wvill receive a cultivation disruption allowance.
-3                     released at the time of acquisition.
-w                 .  Local Consultative Forms (LCFs)* will be established in each affected VDC to
assist SPAFs with the reinvestment of their compensation in other productive
assets. specificallv with the identification and purchasing of suitable privately-
owned cultivation land in the vicinitv.
*  At the request of project authorities. local governiment authorities or LCFs. the
CDCs will be responsible for determining the SPAF statLs of households whose
production levels are deemed to be severely affected. but who do not fall within the
twvo bands as described above.
(d) A titleholder who loses more than 75 % of a land parcel or total landholding. will have
the optioin to relinquishI the remainder of that parcel or landholdine. in return for
assistance witlh thie identification  and purchasing  of replacement land or cash
compensation at replacement cost.
(e) Tenants will be elilible for the portion of the compensation payable to the afiected
landowners as required by HMG9N legislation. Where tenants lose more than 10 % of
__]                the land being cultivated bv them (in the case of a cultivated area less than 0.25 ha) or
more than 25 % ol the land being cultivated (in the case of a cultivated area above 0.25
ha). they wvill receive a cultivation disruption allowance as specified in Section 5.6.
Thev will also be assisted by the LCFs with the identification of alternative
X~1                agricultural production opportunities.
(f1 Temporary  occupation  of privately-owned  land will be undertaken  w-ithin the
1                 framew ork of the Public Roa6 I4c. A temporary occupation contract will be signed
* j                 vwith affected landowners. specify-ing:
*  the period of occupancy:
*  the formula for the calculationi of production losses (the market value of crops
I                      normally produced on the land) and annual inflation adjustments:
*  the frequency of compensation payment: and
7)                 *  land protection and rehabilitation measures.
(g) It is not envisaged that the project -will have a significant impact on communal land
(e.g. grazing land). However. swhere suchI land is acquired by the project. the
Departments of Agriculture and Forestry will assist affected communities in the
improvement of remaining grazing areas and fodder resources to ensure that pre-
Nc10 Road [Xvd-eiopmciit and t pXgrzding Coniponcit                        RAP, Paae 81



Nepal: Road Nlaintenance and Development Project
Final Report: XVolume 8                                          Resettlemnent Actioni Plav.
project levels are maintained or improved upon. Where they are required. these
support programmes wvill be funded by the project.
5.4    CROPS AND OTHER NATURAL RESOLURCES
(a) ConstLuction *works will as far as possible be plained to allow for the harvestina of
non-pereninial and perennial crops before land is acquired. Wihere crops can not be
harvested or the destruction of crops is unavoidable. cash compensation wvill be paid.
based on crop market values as determined by the CDCs. All other resources from
privatelv-owned trees (e.g. timber/fuelwood) will remain the property of the concerned
owner.
(b) Compensation will also be paid for the loss of future production from individually-
owned  fruit. fodder and  timber/fuelwood  trees. and  other perennial crops.
Compensation rates will be calculated by the CDCs. based on five years annual net
productioll for fruit and fodder trees. and three years annual net production for
timber/fuelwood trees and other perennial crops. The annual production value of the
different cateulories of trees will be established by a local natural resource specialist.
(C) Affected owners will additionallv be assisted by the Departments of Forestry and c
Aukriculture with the reestablishment of new trees/perennial crops. Where they are
required. these support pro(grammes will be funded by the project.
(d) Wshere communitv-owned trees are acquired. the Department of Forestry will consult
Wvith user groups re(ardinr  future production losses and compensation modalities.
These consultations will be formallv recorded to ensure equitable access to
relhabilitation and/or compensation measures. User groups will also be assisted with
the reestablishment of new trees/perennial crops and the establishment or improveement
ot community forestry programmes. Where they are required. these support
programmes will be funded by the project.
(e) Loss of trees in the COI will furthermore be mitigated by meanis of afforestation
exercises (as specified in the Puiblic Roccl ALct). to be undertaken by DoR  in
consultation w ith local coimmunities and the Department of Forestry.
DISPLACEMENT ALLOWANCES
In addition to compenisation for asset losses. SPAFs will qualitf- for the follow-inc1
alloNvances:
Nec\ Road Dcclvopnrcnt and t pgradi na Comn ponecnit                      RAP. Paue 82



*              Nepal: Road Maintenance and Developmenl Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                          Resettlement Action Plan
(a) Households who are required to relocate will receive a Housing Displacement
Alliowance equal to two months poverty line income (PLI) (calculated for a household
of 5.5 members).26 Titleholders. tenants in own accommodation and squatters w\ill be
entitled to this allowance. to be paid at the time of compensation payment (see Section
1.3.8).
(b) Owners of commercial enterprises who are required to relocate w-ill receive a Business
j                  Displacement Allowance equal to two months PLI for a household of 5.5 members.
paid at the time of compensation pavment.
(c) Households whose landholdings are no lonoer economically viable as a result of land
losses (as defined in Section 5.3 (b)) will receive a Cultivation Disrutption .41Uowance
equal to one season's production on the area of cultivation land lost. The amount
payable will be based on published District and VDC production figures. land type
(i.e. irri_ated and non-irrigated) and market prices for crops for the year in which the
land is acquired. The allowvance will paid at the time of compensation payment.
(d) The allowances stipulated in para. (a) - (c) will be paid severallv.
(e) Displaced households of rented accommodation will receive a Rented Stipend equal to
0.5 mont,h PLI for a household of 5.5 members. paid at the time of compensation
pavment to the house owvner.
5.6      REHABILITATION MEASURES
(a) Apart from the provision of displacement allowances. the rehabilitation of SPAFs wvill
-J iadditionally be supported through the following measures:
*  counselling regarding project impacts. compensation alternatives and risks. and
resettlement options (where required):
* counselling on saving schemes and cash management;
* preferential access to road construction employment opportunities. to the extent
possible;
*  assessment of current economic activities and potential for improvement to these
3                      activities, as well as alternative income-eaming opportunities;
* assistance with training in life skills: and
*  assistance to gain access to national poverty alleviation and credit programmes.
(b) The Small Farmers Development Programme (SFDP. administered by the Agricultural
Development Bank of Nepal). Production Credit for Rural W'omen (PCRW. Mlinistrv
of Local Development) and the Rural Development Banks and Intensive Bankina
2 PLI will be based on the average per capita income recorded for the MWDR and FWDR in the Nepal
Living Standards Survey (CBS. 1997) and annually adjusted for price escalation (see Annex 13).
Ncv Road Development and Upgrading Component                            RAP. Page S3



Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Voiume 8                                          Resettlement Action Plan
Programme (run bN Commercial Banks) are the main poverty alleviation programmes
adopted by the HMG/N. The project will ensure that these programmes are made
available to SPAFs (e.o. through the proposed Local Consultative Forums) and lobby
for their extension to RMDP areas that mav be poorlv serviced.
(c) The  project \will. in addition. facilitate  the assessment and  (where  feasible)
establishmllent of small-scale incomin_-aenerating schemes for SPAFs. These schemes.
implemented by a number of INGOs and NGOs. include horticulture. sericulture.
handicrafts and bee-keeping.
(d) These rehabilitation measures will be extended to vulnerable groups in the vicinity of
the road corridor who mav be adversely affected bv the project. even though thev do
not lose assets wvithin the COI. These social cateaories will be identified in
consultation with local communities and may include:
*  porters and other non-vehicular transport providers;
*  tribal groups: and
* landless households.
(e) Finalil. throug-h the establishment of Local Consultative Forums (LCFs). PAPs and
local communities will be able to discuss the position of severely affected and
vulnerable people within their communities. monitor their rate of reestablishment. and
recommend additional corrective Measures where necessary.
5.7    GOVERNMENT PROPERTY
(a) Govemment infrastructure and facilities affected by the RMDP will be repaired or
replaced in consultation with the relevant departmental authorities. These include
police stations. oovemment offices and footbridges.
(b) Government forested areas will be acquired in consultation with the Ministry of
Forests.
(c) The loss of ttovemnient trees in the COI will be mitiuated by means of afforestation
exercises (as specified in the Pith/ic Road Act) undertaken by DoR in consultation with    I
the Department of Forestrv.

Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project

6.0 SOCIAL IMPACT MANAGEMENT
Since the RAP deals with a wide range of different communities and complex socio-
economic systems and issues. it wvill alwavs have an element of uncertainty. The emphasis
must. therefore. be on strategic and adaptive management. monitoring of local reactions
and timelv implementation of corrective measures
This Chapter outlines the organisational framework to be established for RAP
implementation. It also discusses monitoring requirements. before concluding with an
overview of the major planning. administrative and logistical requirements for the
successful implementation of the RAP.
6.1   ORGANISATIONAL FRAMEWORK
An organisational setup for RAP implementation is necessarv for three main reasons: (a)
the RMDP covers large. often isolated. areas (11 districts and 58 VDCs) and will require
effective coordination to ensure compliance with policies and procedures: (b) land
acquisition and resettlement activities will place new demands on district officials and
i             local communities: and (c) the implementation of mitigation measures (e.g. fodder
development programmes) requires proper cooperation with other eovernment line
:70           auencies.
As the project authority. DoR will assume overall responsibility for RAP implementation.
As indicated in Chapter Two, this will entail:
*  implementation of procedures to minimise adverse social impacts (acquisition of land
and buildings) throughout the planning. design and implementation phases:
*  implementation of procedures for the recording of all project-affected persons. by
J                means of census and asset verification and quantification exercises:
*  establishment of procedures for the co-ordination of resettlement and compensation
|                 activities on the various road sections:
* establishment of Local Consultative Forums (LCFs) at VDC level:
*  implementation of information dissemination campaigns (e.g. distribution of Nepali
copies of the approved Entitlement Framework)):
*  capacity-building initiatives to create a supportive environment for the implementation
j                 of RAP activities:
* co-ordination with other government line agencies and non-novernmental
or-anisations to ensure effective delivery of mitigation and rehabilitation support
measures.
New Road Development and Upgrading Component                         RAP. Page 91



Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                              Resettlement Action Plan
To ensure the achievement of these activities. organisation for RAP implementation and
management will occur at both central and district project level (see Figure 3). Table 87
shows the various levels of HMG,N staffing requirements for RAP implementation.
Table 87: Staffing Requirements
Level      I               Job Title and Description                    Number
Pro-ramme Co-ordinator                                         I
Central DoR    Social Development Specialist                                   I -
Computer Operator                                                                 -{
Technical Assistance (resettlement and compensation)
Project Manager                                         I per road section
Project      Overseer                                                I per road section  !
Field Assistant                                        4 per road section
Land Survey Official                                      as required
District     Land Revenue Official                                      as required
r   Government  Local Developnment Official                               as required
Support      District AoricLllture Official                             as required
l__________________ bDistrict Forestrv Official                               as required
6.1.1     Central-Level Arrangements
The Programme Co-ordinator will be responsible for overall project coordination and
management. Operating from the DoR head office. the Project Co-ordination Unit (PCU)
will have a small team of DoR support staff dedicated to the social aspects component of
the RMDP. This will include a full time official and a computer operator (to manage the               l
database of affected persons). A social development specialist will. in addition. be
appointed to DoR's Geo-Environmental UInit (GEU) to provide technical assistance and
guidance to the PCU.
The Social Development Support Team within the PCU will be responsible for the
establishment and maintenance of a centralised RAP management svstem. In the
development of this system. particular attention will be paid to:
* procedures for undertaking and completing census and asset verification exercises:
*  intecration of construction, land acquisition and compensation activities:
*  establishment of PAP data bases for each road section. as well as for the project as a
whole:
* procedures for tracking compliance to RMDP policies;.
*  establishment of procedures for ongoing internal monitoring and review of project
level progress reports:
*  procedures for the prompt implementation of corrective actions and the resolution of
grievances:
* establishment of liaison mechanisms to ensure proper technical and lopistical support
to road section project managers and teams. CDCs and Local Consultative Forums
(LCFs): and
l
Ncvs Road DcscIopmcnt and Upgoradingl Cornponecnt                              RAP. Page 92



*             Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                      Resettlement Action Plan
*  establishment of liaison mechanisms to ensure proper technical and logistical support
to road section project managers and teams; and
6.1.2    Project-Level Arrangements
While central level arrangements are necessary for co-ordination of RAP activities. road
section/project-level arrangements are required for effective RAP implementation. Apart
from the formation of Compensation Determination Committees (CDCs). as required by
the Land Acqutisition Act, two additional implementation mechanisms will be established
-~ -at road section/project level: DoR road Project Teams and Local Consultative Forums
(LCFs).
6.1.2.1   Road Section Project lanager and Suipport Teami
Each RMDP road section will be headed up bv a Project Manager. The Project Manager
will have a road section support team. Other relevant district officials (e.g. from the
Departments of Land Surveys and Land Revenue) will be deputed to the RMDP Teams
during the land acquisition process as and when required. The overall function of the Road
Section Project Managers and Teams (with assistance form the Social Development
Support Team within the PCU) will be:
- to establish and maintain consultation mechanisms with the consulting supervising
3                engineer and contractors;
* to integrate construction. land acquisition and compensation activities;
*  to establish proper PAP databases for the road section under its control,
* to establish and maintain effective consultation mechanisms with affected households
and communities;
*  to regularly liaise with the concerned CDC regarding the list of entitled persons.
evacuation notices, compensation payments and grievance resolution:
*  to regularly liaise with the relevant district Land Revenue Office to ensure prompt
transfer of affected land titles to HMG/N; and
*  to ensure implementation of rehabilitation and support measures as detailed in the
Entitlement Policy.
I             A member of the DoR Project Team will attend the LCF meetingzs as shown below. Road
Section Managers will also submit monthly progress reports to the PCU.
j              6.1.2.2   Coordination and Interaction with Otlher Governmentt Departments
The RMDP Project Manager and Social Development Support Team will develop a
programme of interaction with other government departments to ensure effective land
acquisition and compensation and implementation of mitigation measures. The five key
government departments with whom programmes of complementarv planning actions will
be developed are:
New Road Development and Upgrading Component                         RAP, Page 93



Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                        Resettlement Action PLan
*  Ministrv of Home Affairs (Office of the Chief District Officer) - to develop and
overall RMDP implementation programme:
*  Department of Land Revenue and Surveys - to ensure staff availabilitv for asset
verification exercises and to confirm/,enhance land acquisition and transfer procedures:
*  Department of Forestrv - to develop a programme for (a) the timely clearance of trees
from the COI. and (b) the delivery of forestry and fodder improvement schemes to
affected communities:
*  Department of Agriculture - to develop a programme for the delivery of agricultural
support/extension programmes (e.g. agricultural inputs):
*  Department of Local Development - to develop a programme for the delivery of non-
monetary support measures to SPAFs. as well as to provide inputs into general social
development initiatives associated with improved access.
The details of this programme of complementary planning, which will be made available
at line agencv level to guide the actions required for effective RAP implementation. are
outlined in Table 88.
6.1.2.3   Compensatiolz Determinarioni Committees
CDCs will be established in each concerned district according to the provisions of the
Land,Acquisition ALc. The CDCs will also have PAP representation. The CDCs will be
supported by the Social Development Support Team and DoR project teams to ensure
adherence to RMDP policies and effective and prompt determination of compensation
entitlements.
Apart from their normal duties as specified in the Land Acquisition Act. the CDCs will
also be requested to assist with the identification of landowners who may be severelv
affected by land losses. but who do not fall within the SPAF percentage bands as indicated
in the Entitlement Policy.
6.1.2.4   Local Consulltative Foruims
Since the RMDP will deal with large numbers of aff'ected persons. there will always be an
element of riskl attached to the acquisition and compensation procedures. The management
procedures outlined above will therefore be supplemented with an effective local-level
consultation mechanism. Local Consultative Forums (LCFs) will be established in each of
the VDCs crossed by the RMDP roads, either as new entities or around existing road user
committees. LCF composition will be flexible and based on the requirements in each
VDC. The follow-ing membership is envisaged:
*  delegated members from the concerned VDC/Ward:
* representatives from affected communities/households:
* DOR project official;
Ncx~ Ronad Dec\dopjnent and Upgrading Component                        RAP, Page 94



a
Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
IR            Final Report: Volume 8                                          Resettlement Action Plan
* representatives from other concerned line agencies (e.g. Department of Forestry); and
* representatives from local NGOs who may be able to assist with implementation of
support programmes.
Apart from creating a oeneral forum for the discussion of project activities. the LCFs will
specifically be responsible for:
*  assistance to severelv affected landowners with the reinvestment of their compensation
in other productive assets in the vicinitv, through the identification of suitable
privatelv-owned replacement land; and
*  assistance with the recording  and  resolution  of cnievances. Details of LCF
proceedings. progress and constraints will be forwarded to the DoR Project Manager:
*  organising and managing (in conjunction with appointed monitoring consultants)
Participatorv Monitoring and Evaluation (PME) exercises in its areas of operation.
6.1.2.5   Comnuiniyt Liaison Assistants
The feasibility of establishine a system of Community Liaison Assistants (CLAs) will be
assessed bv the LCFs and DoR Project Manager. Where considered necessarv. one or two
CLA  will be appointed (from the affected community) for each project. Apart from
providing support to LCFs. their primary functions will be to:
*  assist with the provision of project information (e.g. implementation schedules) to
affected households:
*  assist with the recording of local grievances and suggestions for discussion with DoR
representatives:
-  assist with fieldwork and meeting arrangements.
6.1.3    NGO Involvement
The RMDP Project Manager and Social Development Support Team  will explore the
possibility of involving suitablv qualified and experienced NGOs in aspects of the
resettlement and rehabilitation activities. in conjunction with district officials and LCFs.
These NGOs would provide grassroots expertise and resources to assist with:
.  project information campaigns to ensure transparency of procedures:
*  communitv-level consultations about entitlements. reinvestment of compensation and
I                  altemative income-generating opportunities:
*  assistance to PAPs to gain access to HMG/N  and non-governmental poverty
alleviation arnd development programmes. or with the assessment and development of
alternative income-seneratin_ activities; and
*  participatory monitorino and evaluation exercises.

6.2    MONITORING AND EVALUATION
The project has an obligation to ensure that affected households regain, and preferably
improve upon. their living standards. The measures detailed in the RAP are designed to
meet this obli2ation. In turn. the implementation of these measures and the extent to which
RAP objectives are being met. require proper checking and assessment. A monitoriniz and
evaluation programme will. accordingly. be implemented to (a) record and assess project
inputs and the number of persons affected and compensated. and (b) confirm that former
subsistence levels and livinc standards are being reestablished.
The range of activities and issues that would therefore have to be recorded and checked.
include:
* land acquisition and transfer procedures:
* compensation payments:
c construction of replacement houses by displaced households;
*  reestablishment of displaced households and business enterprises:
*  reaction  of severelv  affected  households. in  particular. to  resettlement and
compensation packages; and
= reestablishment of income levels.
6.2.1    M&E Indicators and Mechanisms
A ranae of indicators have been established to ensure attainment of RAP objectives. These
are listed in Appendix 15. and summarised below:

3                     The various indicators and benchmarks will be monitored bv means of three monitorina
mechanisms:
*   ongoing  internul tmonitoring  of process  and  output indicators  at both  Central and
District Project level:
* J                 *   pal;iccipctor;:  monitoring anLd evaliuation throu(gh the work of the LCFs; and
Newv Road Development and Upgrading Component                                                   RAP, Page 10 1



I
Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                        Resettlement Action Plan
* mid-term and project concluzsion monitoring and evaluation by external agencies to
assess the extent to which resettlement and rehabilitation objectives have been met.
6.2.2    Internal Monitoring
Ongoing monitoring of land acquisition. compensation and resettlement will occur as a
standard activitv of road section Project Managers and the                                l
The Project Manager will submit monthly progress reports to the RMDP Programme Co-
ordinator. indicating number of affected persons. compensation effected. grievances and   I
problems. and corrective measures implemented or required.
Members of the Road Section DoR Teams will attend LCF meetings as and when
required. They will record and monitor local reactions. concerns and grievances for
discussion with the Project Manager. The LCFs will play an important monitoring role by
providing feedbackl on community conceres. grievances and requests.
6.2.3    Participatory Monitoring and Evaluation
Participatorv monitoring and evaluation (PME) will be an additional method through
which the attainment of resettlement and compensation objectives will be assessed. PME     S
will involve periodic assessment workshops in different settlements. involving a sample of
affected households from different social categories. Special attention will be Given to
securing the participation of women.
The workshops will provide households the opportunity to discuss both the positive and
negative aspects of their resettlement, compensation and reestablishment. An inclusive
problem-solving approach will be followed. using local experiences and realities as the
basis for solutions.
SuitablN qualified local organisations will be appointed to undertake training in and
conduct the PME exercises.
6.2.4    External Monitoring
Two monitoring surveys of a sample of affected households will be undertaken to assess
the degyree to which RAP objectives have been met. The sample survey will cover all the    I
cateaories of affected households.
An important aim of the sample monitoring survev will be to measure the extent to which    I
household subsistence agricultural production levels and living standards have been
restored/improved. Information obtained from  the sample socio-economic surve) and
census will set the baseline for measurement of living standard restoration. For effective
comparison and assessment. the monitoring survey w-ill therefore include data collection
on the following:
Nc%s Koad Development and Upgrading Component                         RAP. Page 102



Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                          Resettlement Action Plan
* household composition. demographv and occupation and employment levels.
a  children's education,
*  crop output and production costs;
* household assets;
*  income and expenditure: and
* consumption patterns.
6.2.5    Monitoring of Social Issues and Development Trends
It is likelv that unanticipated or indirect social issues and impacts may emerge during RAP
implementation. These issues will be identified for further action (where required) through
the local-level consultation structures and formal monitoring programmes. The following
are tvpical issues that mav require further assessment and action during the course of
project implementation:
* changes to land use tenure and patterns along the roads;
c changes to settlement pattems and market centres:
*  increased indebtedness and mortgaging of land:
* changes in gender and ethnic/caste relations:
*  development of. or increases in. "social pathologies" such as alcoholism and STDs:
* disturbances to the social practices and fabric of local communities (e.g. influx of job
c i                seekers. development of informal settlements: pressure on local authorities to maintain
autonomy).
Finally, although not directly related to the RAP. DoR will cooperate with the Department
of Local Development and the concemed DDCs to establish a programme for the
monitoring and evaluation of broader social development issues associated with improved
}_J            access from new road construction. This programme should consider changes to. inter
ciliu:
*  land use patterns;
*  agricultural production levels;
*  off-farm economic activities:
*  local development initiatives;
* population distribution and settlement patterns:
* health indicators; and
*  school attendance and literacy rates.
New Road Development and Upgrading Componcnt                            RAP, Page 103



Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                                     Resentlement Action Plan
6.3    IMPLEMENTATION
The previous sections described the organisational framework necessary for
implementation of RAP activities. This final section considers the complementary plan of
actions required for RAP implementation.
6.3.1      Construction Schedule and RAP Implementation
Road construction and uporading will occur over a four vear period, and is scheduled to
commence in January 1999. Construction will commence in the first year on all the new
road sections. with the exception of Chhedegad-Jajarkot which is scheduled to start in the
second  year. Uparadingi works commence early in the first vear on Surkhet-Kalikot. and a
few months later on Dharapani-Chhedegad and Gorusinge-Sandh ikharka.

6.3.2      Key Implementation Issues
6.3.2.1    Census ofAffectedPersons and Assets
A census of potentially affected persons and their assets has been completed for most of
the road sections. with the remaining sections scheduled for completion bv end-July 1999.
Information obtained from this exercise is summarised in Attachments 8 to 10. and 12.
A PAP database has been developed and census information is currently being captured by
DoR. This activity is scheduled for completion bv November 1999. The list of affected
persons  and  assets  will be  re-verified  prior  to  construction/upgrading  works. and
adjustments  made  to  the  PAP  database. The  verified  lists of affected  persons and
properties will be made available to the relevant CDO. CDC and LCF.
New Road Development and Upgrading Component                                           RAP, Page 105



Nepal: Road Maintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                      Resettlement Action Plan
6.3.2.2   Deployment and Train?ing of Staff
The deplovnent of DoR staff at central and road section level (as indicated in Table 42)
has commenced. and will be completed according to the project construction schedule. A
DoR official has recentl been seconded to assist with RAP related issues. while a
computer operator has been made available to complete input of PAP data generated
duriny the ongoinga census and asset verification. Summarised copies of PAP information
is beincg made available to the relevant Road Section Managers as data input is completed.
A general programme of capacitv building for DoR staff commenced in May 1999. A
workshop was held wNith the DoR  Road Section Managers to discuss social and
environmental implementation issues. and other general matters. A training session was
also held with the DoR computer operator and social development officer on the
development and maintenance of th'e PAP database. including procedures for the
dissemination of updated PAP information between central and road project level.
Additional capacity-buildino will occur during project implementation. This programme
will have the followin- aims:
* to create/enhance awareness of RMDP policies and procedures;
• to provide training in the establishment of compensation plans for each affected
household and PAP databases for each road section.
*  to provide training on internationall' accepted  resettlement and rehabilitation
practices: and
*  to provide training on participatorv action research.
Components of this programme will also be presented (on site) to community
representatives as part of the PME training to be undertaken by an NGO.
6.3.2.3   Procedlures for thze Transfer of Land Titles
A kev activity to be undertaken by the Social Development Unit within the PCU will be to
monitor the transfer of land titles from affected owners to HMG/N. A first priority wvill be
to ensure that land alreadv acquired for the initial construction of the upgrading road
sections (see list of names in Attachment 12) is transferred to HMG/N.
6.3.2.4   Coordination vithz Otiher GovernmentAgencies
Reference was earlier made to the coordination required with other (government line
aglencies to ensure effective delivery of support measures to SPAFs. The Social
Development Support T'eam. with assistance from the (to be appointed) social
development specialist. will further develop the plan of complementary actions indicated
in T'able 88. to ensure that agreed action plans are in place for development delivery by the
time of project implementation.

DoR).
