7.1.3     Land Acquisition
Land in Nepal is grouped into different tvpes and classes. which, in turn. form the basis for
the calculation of land taxes. The main land tvpes are khet. bari and kharbari. Khei is
irrigated Land. generallv situated in valleys and mainly used for paddy rice and wheat
production. Since it is mostly situated on hill slopes. PaSkho and Bari are not irrizated and
mainlv used for rainfed crop production. Kharbari is grassland used for harvesting of         j
grasses for thatchine. etc. Both kher and bari/Pakho are subdivided into the following land
classes: Aclddrni (class I land); Dovani (class 2 land); Sim (class 3 land); and Chahcar (class
4 land). For budget purposes. onlv the two main land types (khet and Pakho) are used for
cultivation land losses. Rates for class 4 Pakho land are used for other non-cultivation land
(e.g. residential plots).
Official land prices are calculated annually at district level for each of the different land
tvpes and classes. These prices are used as the basis for the payment of land taxes. It is
stated that official land rates often do not reflect actual market values. inter alia because of
under-valuation for land tax purposes. At the same time. persons along a new road
alignment may report inflated land prices in anticipation of compensation payments.
Three sources of information have been used in estimating land value for budget purposes:
(a) official government rates. (b) information gleaned during the walkover and detailed
surveys and (c) information obtained from the household questionnaires (17 household
indicated that they sold land in the previous year). Government land rates have been
obtained for most of the road districts. These have been included in Annex 11 of the RAP.
Again, to simplify the budgeting process. average land rates have been calculated from
these district figures for khet. pakho and other private land. Averapes for high value
turban" areas have been caiculated separatelv. A similar process was followed for the
calculation of averagye land rates reported during the survev. although rates that were
considered to be abnormally high were not used in the calculations (see Annex 11 of the
RAP). The three land rates are given below.
Table 97: Average Land Rates
Average Rate per Ropani (in NRs)

Other private land              3.9213
Higzh *-alue -urban"          55.997                 147.000                                   5

other private land by 20%. and to use these rates. plus the unadjusted government rate for
hi-her value areas. for budget purposes. The rates are:                                         -i
*  klihet:                  NRs 16.801 per ropani:

7.2      REHABILITATION SUPPORT
This cost item covers two support measures for severelv affected individuals and
households:
* displacement allowances: and
* support with alternative income generation and training in occupational/life skills.
7.2.1    Displacement Allowances
The Entitlement Framework provides for three tvpes of allowvances (housing and business
displacement allowances and a cultivation disruption allowance). as well as rental stipends
for displaced occupants of rented accommodation.
Housine and business displacement aljlow-ances are based on two month's household
income from information obtained in Nepal Living Standards Survey (CBS. 1997). and
annually adjusted for price escalation. The NLSS recorded per capita incomes (1996
values) of.respectively NRs 6.038 and NRs 5.982 for the MWDR and FWDR. This 2ives
an average per capita income of NRs 5.983 (1996 values) and NRs 7,962 (10% annual
escalation to 1999) for the two regions. Displacement allowances will amount to
NRs 7.299 (1999 value). calculated as follows:                                              u
* NRs 7.962 x 5.5 average household size/12 x 2 months).
Rental stipend is based on 0.5 month household income as defined above.
Cultivation disruption allowances are based on one season's paddy production on the area
of cultivation lost (see Annex 11 for crop market prices). An amount of NRs 4.300 has
been used for budget purposes (average loss of 0.43 ropani at NRs 10.000 per paddy
season).
Cost estimates for these allowances are shown below.
Table 100: Displacement and Rehabilitation Allowances
Road Section

7.2.2    Income Generation and Life Skills
This item covers support to severely affected persons with the reestablishment of their
livelihoods, the development of new income-generating opportunities and trainina in life
skills. It is envisaged that the work will be umdertaken by suitabiv qualified local NGOs.
I             with support from DoR and other government line aaencies.
The cost is based on an estimated 1-.565 severel project affected persons at an average of
-w            NRs 8.000 per PAP.
Total cost for inicome generation/life skill developmelrt amounnot to NVRs 12.520 million
(USS 0.186M).
7.3      IMPLEMENTATION AND MANAGENIENT
This cost item covers the organisational arrangements required for the implementation and
management of resettlement-related activities. It includes information dissemination
campaigns and costs for Local Consultative Forum (LCF) meetings..
7.3.1    Information Dissemination
I             This cost item covers information dissemination campaigns (project-area meetinas and the
distribution of information fact sheets) to ensure full understanding of entitlements and
J            compensation procedures. A total of 200 meetings. at an averaze of NRs 10.000 per
meeting, has been budgeted for. Budgeted cost amounts to NRs 2.00 million
(US$ 0.030 M).
7.3.2    LCF Meetings
This cost item covers meeting support to the Local Consultative Forums. A total of 348
l            meetings (58 LCFs holdinc two annual meetiRgs over a period of three years) has been
budgeted for, at a cost of NRs 7.000 per meeting. Budgeted costs amounts to NRs 2.436
million (US$ 0.036 M).
I             Total cost for implementation anad management amouint to NRs 4.436 million
(US$ 0. 066 M).
7.4      MONITORING
An amount of NRs 15.0 million (US$ 0.223 M) has been budgeted for two monitoring
exercises (mid-term and project conclusion) to be undertak-en by local oraanisations.

7.5    CONTINGENCIES
A contingency amount of NRs 5.068 (5%  of compensation and rehabilitation costs) has
been included for the full acquisition of land parcels affected bv more than 75%.

Nepal: Road Mainienance and De'eiopment Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                              Resettlement Action Plan
AN NEX 4
DISTRICT PROFILE
1.     DARCHULA DISTRICT
1.1   Introduction
Darchula district is located alonu the .Mahakail river in the Far Western Developmenrt Region
of Nepal. It had a pOpuliation of 101.683 in 1991. The population has been estimated to be
1  110.'61 wvith an anu-ial gro\th rate of 1.203 in 1998. The total area of the district is z.3  sq.
km. The district is surrounded by Bajhang in the east. Baitadi in thle south. China in the nortlh
and India in the west. It has 41 Vilage Development Committees. The total number of
househods were 18.700 in 1996.
1.2    Economic Activities
Nearly 46 % of the population are economicallv active in the district. of wvhich 90 %JO are
depending on aariculture and fishing. Remittance is one of the main source of income of the
people. Mlost of the people go to Pitthourasgad . Nainital. Delhi in search of work.
Miaize (11.140 \IT) and Wheat (8.657 MT) are the major cereal crops followed by Paddy
(4.075 MT) and Mlillet (1.650 'NIT) in terms of production. Potato is the only major cash crop
fl            of the district. In 1994/95. 4.305 MT of potato was produced in the district.
Livestock rearing is also one of the major occupation of the people. In 1994/95. the district
lhad 78.722 cattle. 71.448 goats. 41.934 buffaloes. 21.242 sheep and 193.000 fowls.
The per capita income ot'the district was Rs. 4.876 in 1996.
13     Social Services
1.3.1  Educationi
The district had 180 primar. 341loVer secondary and 27 hi(h schools. Due to proximity and
access. people usually go to India for basic and higlher education.
1.3.2  Health
Thie district has one ihospital. one primarv health centre (under constructioni in Gokuleshllvor).
I 1 health posts and 29 sub-health posts. It nmeans that one health institution is providing
health facilities to more than 2.500 population in the district.
New Road Development and Upgrading Component                                Annex 4. Page I



4
Nepal: Road M-laintenance and Development Project
Final Report: Volume 8                                            Resertlemenr Action Plan
1.3.3 \Market
The main mark-et centre are Gokuleshlor. Dhap and Darchula. where the marketine activities
occur. Due to proXilmity to India. major trading and business occur w%ith  India. Thus the
woods are imported from India and distributed to different parts or the district throu_gh imules
and porters
1.3.4  Electricitv
A small 300 kN;. Of hvdro power plant has been installed in Dumre. Khalan-a VDC. The
electricitv has been distributed to some settlements of Khalanga. Dhap. Kote. Chhapre VIDCs.
About 1000 houseliolds are enjoying thle facilities at the moment.
1.4    Labour Availabilitv
Liket Achham and Bajura. people of darchula usually go to India in search of work. Howvever.
they are available if they receive Rs.160 per day as they were t'ettingI in India.. The local
people are very mItch aware of working witlh the local contractor. Sometimes they have not
been paid for a long time or paid very less than thev have been told to pav. The following is  U
one of the case story- of one labourer wvho was exploited by a INiepalese contractor.
;
Case Studv I

2.     BA,JURA DISTRICT
i            2.1    Introduction
Bajura is one of the remote mountain district of Far Western Development Region of Nepal.
It is surrounded by Kalikot in the east. BaJhang in the wvest. Humla and Muzu in the north and
Accham and Doti in the South.
The district had a population of 92.0 10 in 1991. It is estimated to be 106.300 in 1998 with an
annual Lyroxwth rate of 2.09 °'. The total area of the district is 2.168. The total number of
households W'ere 19.368 with an avera-e household size of 5.3 in 1996
It has 27 Village development Committees and 9 Illak-as. Mlartadi. the headquarter of Bajura.
_              lies above 500 ft. from thre sea level. Tate ( Kuldemandu VDC)  vas the headquarter of
Bajura from 201 9 B.S. ( 1962) to 2034 (1977). The district lheadquarter wvas shifted from Tate
Mto  artadi since Jestha 9. 2034 B.S.
2.2    Economic activities
About 56 % of the total population of the district are economicallv active . A-riculture is the
main occupation of the inhabitants. About 93.5%O of the economically active population
depend on agriculture and fishina. Livestock farmingJ is one of the prerequisites ot the
farmers. They have been reared for manure as wxell as for land ploughing purpose. In
1991495. the district had 55.738 cattle. 45.988 goats. '6.732 buffaloes. 17. 464 sheep and
2J0.974 fowls. Padd% (5.765 .\IT) and Wheat (5.'210 NIT) are the major food crops follow-ed b\
-Millet (2.990 NIT) and Nlaize (1.697 MT) of the district. Potato (4.500 NIT') is the only majcr
-* |cash crop of the district
The per- capita incomlle of the district w-as Rs. .428 in 1')96.
The district has an annual deficit of k6.1 36 NIT o' food in 1994:95. This shows that substantial
lIamoIunt of cereals have to be imported to fed the population in tlle district.

It had a population of 198.188 in 1991. It has been estimated to be 207.800 with ar. annual
gTrowth of 0.679 in 1998. The totai area of the district is 1680 sq. meter. The district is

to the north. It has 75 Village Development Committees. The total number of households
were 40.276 wvith an averaue size of households of 5.1 in 1996.
3.2    Economic Activities

and major source of livelihood. Nearly 97 % of these active population are solelN depend on
auriculture and fishin2 activities. The district is heavil, deficit in food. It has a deficit of
'3.322 NIT of food in i 995,96.

3.5    Compensation procedure for the loss of house and building                                 m
at the time road construction
The road department/project office has paid money in form of compensation for those who
had lost their land durinue construction. But there was no provision for the compensation of
land tha. has been used for construction.
In Achhlam district. DOR has fixed two rates for coompensation of buildino  lost durine the
construction. The owner. -who constructed  hiis house after 1993. had received Rs. 101) per
cu.tt. and the house built before 1988 and then up to 1993 had received Rs. 60 per cu.h.
The supervisor ( %Mr. Prem Budda) fi-om road office. Manualsen was in charge of measuring
the house structure. Wv'hile tixing the compensation. he had to look the type of house (i.e.
muid. brick. cement). roofing pattern ( i.e. slate. tin. timber). number of storev. door and
vinuowx t-pe ( i.e. timber. tin). heihLt. length. breadth ( cU. ft.) of the hiouse structure. After
this he had calculated the the total cost of the house. The total cost of the  buildinus or
aff,ected families had been sent to the compensation committee in district. The committee
consisted of CDO. DDC chairpersoni. representatiVe from DDCO. police oftice . enmineer.
Thle comnmittee fixed the compensation amount for indiidual household and then forwarded
to Dipa\ al road division. After re-ie\vinl  the statement sent by the project office and the     I
comllpensation committet. Dipa%al road division sent mollne to C'DO office for distribution.

Nepal Road Mainterancc and Devclopmcllt Projecl
Final Report: Volume 8                                             Resettlemeint Action Plan
IMPLEMENTATION ISSUES
1     Land Acquisition Procedures
The land acquisitioni procedures for the RNIDP (based on the stipulations of the Lund
Acquisilion, 4c and additional proceduLres specified in the Entitlemiienit Policy) cosisiSt of:
(a) censLIs of personIs affected by road constrLctioll!upcradi 1a:                                3
(b) verification of land. buildings and privately-owned trees to be acquired by the pro ject: (as
well as counselineg on entitlement options):
(c) publicationi of acquisition  notice by Chief District O1-ficer:
(d) determiniationl  of entitled  persons  and  establishmllenit  of compenisationi by  the
Compensation Determiinationi Committees.
(e) p,tblication of list of entitled personis:
(f) serving of notice to vacate (35 days prior to INIGN taking possession of thc properties
in question):
(g) where a house or business is displaced. payment of a displacemenlt allowance and
compensation advrance at the time of notice to vacate (i.e. 35 days prior to HN4G/N takline
possession of the property);
(h) for otlher buildings (e.g. slheds) and land. compenisation payable on the date of acquisition.
togetlher with the issuillcn of com,pensation certificates:                                    A
(i) paymeent of agricultural disruption allowance to SPAFs:
(j) implemenitation of rehabilitation support measures. where applicable: and
(k) transfer of land titles to 1-1MG/N.
2      Integration of Land Acquisition and Civil Works
A key objective of the Entitlement Policy is that civil xvorks wvill nlot commence on any of the
road sections until land acquisition procedures have been successfully initiated. It w,vill.
therefore. be necessarv to carefully intelrate acqLuisition procedures and civil wvorks. to ensure
that this objective is met.
It would obviously not be practical to prohibit construction work until all thle steps listed
above have been completed. In terms of the Land Acquisition .4ct. at least 15  day's should be
provided after issuing of the Acquisition Notice (step (c) above) by the CDO  for the
submission of compenisation claims and other complaints. The Notice should also specify the
evacuation period. However. evidence from otlher projects shovs that the HMG,N may take
possession of the land at an! time after the Notice had been issued.
Acquisition procedures have been specified in more detail on the RMDP. to allow- P.APs
sufficient time to manke evacuation arrangemnents. Accordingly. civil works on a particular
stretch of road will not commence until the completion of steps (a) - (g). Thiis does not
include the resolutioni of complaints lodged at a court of law (e.g. over ownership), since the
Act does not allow for such cases to delay land acquisition under the right of public domain.
The DoR Project Manager and Social Development Support Team iwill be responsible for
ensuring that these acquisition procedures are incorporated into the scheduling of contracts
and timing of civil works.
New Road Develooiient and UDLradine Prnieet                               Anne\ 1 r-n 1

Darchula Road Alignment
The proposed Darcliula alignment. sLartini  at the enid of currient roacdworks  ,3.000 kmi fri-om

km up to 100.00 knm mark. This initial 7 km of alignment \\as refined duling the walk-over
inspection to avoid unistable or steep sites and loops./hairpins.
I'he  proposed  alignment descendls from  the  cuLrenit roadhead  at 93.000  km  down
approximatelv 50 ni Tuakltiiali village via two svitchbacks through grassland and with some
irainfed cultivation. It theni rtinis at a minior grade Up to the Soutilelnl enld of Tliaktlhali village.
:-.J          parallel to the riatht bank- of the Gadet Klhola. mainly throLughl1 steelp grasslands with some
patchies of rainifed cultivation. It theni IUIIs northwards at a minior Lradient to approximatcly
50 m below Tlialktilali villace.
The alianmenit drops down to the Bartola Khola v ia 8-1I 0 switchbacks throuph Somarlibali and
Simnaldhukuri villages. The main land/types crossed by the s\\itchbacks are steep grasslands
(comprised mainly of thatchi grasscs) and degraded siLrublaicis on limestolne bedrock. The
alig-nment then crosses the Bartola Khola belox M/Ielakhet village and ascends graduallv to
Bartola villaoe. The aliinienlt thieln generally follows the existiiLn trail via Dhiumari. Bliartola
and Ansinmada villages ruLinning parallel to the Bhartola Khola. It thien crosses a moderately
dense Sal and tropical mixedi hardwood government forest. renerl-ilv fo10oWiLn tile existin
trail abouIt 1 00 m vertical above the Bhai-tola lKhola.
At about 100 m vertical above the conifluence o' the Bliartola lKhola and iclahakali River. the
alignment turns northwards riuninga parallel to the left (easterin) ban<k of the MIaha'Kali RiVer.
It then rUns at a minor orade ul) to Bet village mainly through steep grasslands.
From  Bet village. the aliinment generally follows the eXistinu trail to Darhiul.ia. runtilli
--            parallel to the Mlahakali River approximately I 0-2) m vertical above waler level. It thienl
crosses the Chuticiain Klhola below a moderately dense immature forest. thenl ascencls behlincl

Mancalsen Road Alignment

the Radha ricloe.

Biizirma. Lihi. KIuda1i. Raka. Litakot. Larmi. Nawaahat. Urn Khola. Slhredisk;a and near .Tumla
U              llKhalanga. The road alignment only leaves the trail in sections where grade improvement is
requiled or wlhere facilities such as setileetiieits and individual houses.
